text: Blue sky, a few puffs of cloud, pierced by slanting rays sunlight. Late afternoon on a perfect day.
As we hear, after a few more beats, an ASTRONAUT'S VOICE.
T minus ten, nine, eight, start  ignition sequence, five, four, three,  two, one, ignition... Liftoff!
A tiny red streak zips into the sky, then bursts with a f ludicrous POP. A bottle rocket. We hear CHILDREN'S LAUGHT excited SHOUTS.

head_text.subj: EXT. LAWN PARTY. LUKE GRAHAM'S HOUSE. LATE AFTERNOON

text: DESCENDING, we see PHIL OHLMYER, late 20's, kneeling, wit gaggle of eager CHILDREN around him. Phil, an astronaut, got an impressive array of fireworks lined up, and is usi an empty longneck as his launching tube.
(all at once) My turn! My turn! No, I was next!  No, me! Uncle Phil, Uncle Phil, can  I do one? I want to do one!
Guys, guys, please! This is risky  stuff here. And I'm a highly trained  professional.
Derisive GROANS from the kids, more SHOUTS. Phil grins.  There's little danger NASA will ever use him on a recruit poster: he's messy, very hyper. Phil waves his hands for  silence.
Okay, okay! Uncle Phil will launch  another booster...
Another astronaut, RENEE COTE, a tall, very fit French wo is walking by with a fresh six-pack. She tosses a beer an Phil catches it.
...just as soon as he completes his  fuel intake.

Who grins, walking away from Phil and the kids, as we beg to get a better sense of the scope of this party. We are the big back yard of a middle-class home in a Houston sub DOZENS OF PEOPLE - astronauts, NASA personnel, and their  families -- are gathered around picnic tables or spread-o blankets. Lots of red, white and blue bunting, lots of  balloons. We hear snatches of MUSIC, mostly country-flavo from dueling boomboxes. Futuristic Frisbees are being tos about. A banner, strung between trees, reads "BON VOYAGE,
It'll take us six months just to get  to Mars. Another year on the surface,  then six months back. That's two  years...

Passing the banner, Cote lobs a beer to another astronaut NICHOLAS WILLIS, who snags it neatly. He's got his other around the waist of a PRETTY GIRL. As Cote moves OUT OF F ANGLE LINGERS on these two. Willis, a very young astronau early 20s, is recruiting poster material, and knows it al too well.
I guess what I'm trying to say is,  since this is my last night on Earth,  it's gonna be a very precious memory  to me. Y'know?
Nice try, Nick.

As the Pretty Girl slips out of his grasp, laughing, and  walks away, Willis shrugs philosophically. He pops open h beer, swigs it. ANGLE FOLLOWS THE PRETTY GIRL As she swerves around an op pit barbecue, where other ASTRONAUTS are gathered. Cote h paused here, too, distributing the last of her beers. SER KIROV, a Russian cosmonaut, is watching some kids nearby they play a game of wiffle ball. He turns, grinning beeri at the chef.
Hey, Woody, our Mars One crew won't  be heading back to Earth till ten  days after you guys land at our base  camp with Mars Two. That's a pretty  good long rendezvous.

WOODY BLAKE, late 30s, is a big, rangy guy in a cowboy ha over a Hawaiian shirt and a "KISS THE CHEF" apron. An ent pig is turning on a spit over the flames, and Woody is ba this as he smiles at Malik.
What are you suggesting, Sergei?
Maybe you should bring a baseball  bat. Yes? American baseball? Our two  crews could have ourselves a little  Solar System Series.
Please. Half you guys are foreigners.  We'd crush you.
No, no, we have equal crews. Three  men, one woman. Same handicap.
He grins teasingly at Cote, who makes a face at him.
Easy now, you're talking about my  wife. (seeing her approach) And Terri just happens to be one  helluva shortstop.

DR. TERRI FISHER, early 30s, passes by with a platter of  corn-on-the-cob. Short, sturdy body, a face made attracti by its alert, questing intelligence. She pauses to kiss  Woody's cheek; there's a wonderful, sexy spark between th Then she glances at Kirov, all business now.
Fast pitch, no steals, batter calls  his own strikes. Thousand bucks make  it interesting?
He's a bit rattled by her cockiness, and looks at Cote, w smiles, nods her cool agreement.
Eh bien. Winner take all.
Good. (smiles sweetly at  Kirov) Bring some balls.
The other men ooooh at this, busting on Kirov and Cote, a Terri moves on. Woody, watching her go, has a thousand-wa grin.
You wanna know the sad part?  Technically I outrank her. But if we  want any peace at all on Mars Two,  I'm gonna be saying a lot of "Yes,  dears."

The others laugh. ANGLE FOLLOWS TERRI as she dodges a PACK OF KIDS -- they by her, shrieking happily - before she finally reaches a  picnic table, where ASTRONAUTS' WIVES are opening contain of baked beans, coleslaw, and potato salad.
...just not sure how I feel about  NASA allowing couples to go on this  type of mission together.
One of the other women raises a warning eyebrow, and the Wife turns, sees Terri setting down her platter.
(embarrassed) Nothing personal, Terri. It's just  that, well, it's kind of a funny  feeling for those of us staying  behind.
(carefully neutral) All the research shows that marriage  will provide stability on these long  duration trips.
Then they haven't studied some of  the couples I've known.

Laughter at this. Terri smiles politely -- she doesn't re have much in common with these women -- before moving on. ANGLE LINGERS on the wives, who watch her go with a sligh tinge of jealousy. One of them is looking around.
Anybody seen Jim McConnell?
I don't think he's coming.
God, that poor man. How's he doing?
Totally losing it, from what I hear.  Can't sleep, can't eat. Visits her  grave almost every day. (lowers her voice) They say he could lose mission status.
Oh, that's so sad. That is just so  tragic. You go to a routine physical  one day, and wham.
After all those years of training,  too. It was their whole dream.
Must be a pretty funny feeling for  Luke Graham. Y'know? Now he's gonna  be in the history books. First man  on Mars...

She shakes her head, awed by the thought. The others nod agreement, following her glance... In the distance, a lone MALE FIGURE stands by the garage, his back to them, facing the parked cars, vans, and SUVs  which stretch down the driveway and along the street. Ano figure, a WOMAN, can be seen approaching him. CLOSER ANGLE FOLLOWS the moving woman -- DEBRA GRAHAM, ea 30s, very attractive -- until she reaches her husband. LU GRAHAM, mid 30s, has the lean, fit body of an astronaut, restless intellect of a scientist. He's unaware of her  approach until she touches his shoulder. He looks at her  with an apologetic smile.
He's not coming, Luke.
Jim deserves this, too. All his  friends are here. And it's my last  night.
(gently) Your last night with us, too.
He looks at her, moved. She summons a smile. He slides hi arms around her waist, kisses her forehead.
I love you, Deb.
I love you too, baby. But maybe you  should spend some time with Bobby.
Yeah. I will. Where is he?
Up in his fort.
He kisses her again, then goes. Debra's eyes follow him,  with a mixture of pride and sadness. ANGLE FOLLOWS Luke away from the garage, into

head_text.subj: EXT. THE BACK YARD. LATE AFTERNOON

text: Luke moves through the crowd. Phil and the kids are still shooting off rockets. Red streaks arc high overhead. In the back corner of the yard, where it's quieter, he pa Willis, who's sitting on a blanket, murmuring soulfully t PRETTY GIRL #2.
Deep space is so lonesome. So cold.  But I guess I'll have my memories to  keep me warm...

Luke shakes his head. Willis is incorrigible. Finally he  reaches a tall redwood playset. He looks up the ladder. A SMALL BOY sits on the platform of the tower, arms aroun his knees, staring up at the stars. A telescope rests nea on a tripod. He looks lonely. Luke climbs up, sits down on the wooden deck next to him. BOBBY, 7, glances over at his dad, his idol, then back at the sky.
Who's gonna read to me now, at  bedtime?
Luke is surprised by the question. A pause.
Mommy will.
I like when you do it. Now we're  never gonna finish our book.
His voice is unexpectedly fierce. He's fighting back tear Luke is moved. Another brief silence.

Well, I'll tell you what. I've been  thinking about that. And what I  thought was -- how 'bout if I bring  along my own copy? (Bobby looks at him) Then every night, wherever I am,  I'll read a little bit more of it.  And I'll know that you and Mommy,  wherever you are, you're reading it  too. That way, it'll feel like we're  still reading it together. 'Cause I  don't know about you, but I'm pretty  anxious to find out how 'ol Ben Gunn  got marooned on that island. What  d'you say?
Bobby manages a smile. He nods, feeling a little better.  Luke is proud of his son's courage.
Good deal. Can I have a hug?

Bobby's arms go around his father's neck. He hugs Luke  fiercely, and Luke hugs him back. His eyes, over the thin young shoulders, are brimming with love and impending abs Then, from the distance, the sound of an APPROACHING CAR. They both turn. An open Jeep is coming down the street. Its DRIVER is alo Luke's expression changes. Recognition, then happiness.

The Jeep stops, its electric engine WHIRRING down. The Dr climbs out wearily, reaching into the back seat, and come out with a champagne bottle, hastily decorated with ribbo The PARTY SOUNDS are drifting this way, and he hesitates moment, seeming to gather himself. He starts gamely towar the party, then pauses again. Debra Graham stands nearby on the front lawn, waiting. Sh smiles tentatively. JIM MCCONNELL, early 40s, manages a smile in return. He h dark circles under his eyes, and his clothes look slept i Yet we sense, even through his sadness, a kind of quiet  competence in this man, an unforced authority; he's a nat leader. Debra hurries forward, into his arms, and he hugs her. Th separate, looking at each other. Her eyes are shining.
We were afraid you wouldn't come.
I caught a whiff of your barbecue.  After that I was helpless.
All the way out in Galveston?
Something like that. (she smiles) It's his night, Deb. I didn't want  to spoil it.
Spoil it? He's been going crazy  looking for you.
Over her shoulder he sees Luke approaching, his arm aroun Bobby. The two men look at each other, the bond between t so strong it needs no words. Finally Luke smiles.
C'mon. A whole lot of folks here are  gonna be mighty glad to see you.
McConnell comes towards him, accompanied by Debra, and  together the four of them move OUT OF FRAME, heading towa the party. ANGLE HOLDS on the parking area, as we...

All the parked cars and vans are gone now, except for two McConnell's Jeep and Woody's classic 'Vette. Willis, one the last to go, is just departing on his motorcycle. Perc behind him, arms around his waist, is PRETTY GIRL #3. The zoom away, through the darkened neighborhood.

The yard is nearly deserted. The "Bon Voyage" banner has  torn loose at one end and flutters limply. Here and there napkin blows across the ground. In the distance, THREE FIGURES sit on the ground, by the  waning fire of the barbecue pit, sipping beers.

As Woody shoves another piece of wood into the flames. Fo moment he, McConnell, and Luke are silent, staring at the sparks as they rise towards the stars -- red and gold dot mingling with the silver ones.
(abruptly) I wish we were all going. Together.
The intensity in his voice surprises the others, and even Woody himself. Luke glances at McConnell. An awkward beat
Then you've got a short memory. Think  back to how we were by the second  week of lunar training.
Oh, you're not gonna bring that up  again --
(laughing) I'm trying to remember, let's see,  which one of us scored the lowest  ranking up there?
You just can't let that go --
Oh, man, three commanders, on the  same ship? If they sent us off to  Mars together, there wouldn't be  enough fuel to lift all those egos.
(laughs) Bullshit, we would've made a great  crew.
That was never gonna happen. I was  always teamed with Maggie, and we  were mostly chalkboard jockies. You  know? Systems. Payloads...
Listen to him. Mr. Cover-of-Time  Magazine!
Yeah, who landed the crippled Block  II Shuttle?
Yeah, and who scored highest on the  lunar rankings?
Let it go, Luke.

(smiles) Sure, I made a little noise. But  putting the first footprints on Mars?  Nah. That's for guys who... (looks at Luke) ...wrote their Ph.D. thesis on how  to colonize the place. And guys who... (looks at Woody) ...read too much science fiction as  a kid and still wear little Flash  Gordon rocketships around their necks.
He grabs playfully at Woody's neck. Woody smacks his hand away, laughing.
You read the same damn science fiction  books that I did! You're just not  man enough to wear jewelry!
He pulls from his shirt a little Flash Gordon rocketship  emblem hanging on a chain, and waggles this tauntingly at McConnell, as Luke and McConnell laugh.
You want Flash. You know you want  him. Well you'll have to come through  me!
Luke grabs Woody's arm to give McConnell a better shot at the emblem, but Woody cuffs his hands away, laughing.  McConnell, watching their horseplay, shakes his head.
God, she would've loved to see you  two clowns. Just one more time.

He tries to smile, but his face reddens. Then all at once his chest is heaving as he struggles to control his emoti Woody sees this, reaches out a reassuring hand, but McCon shakes him off, rises abruptly. He turns his back on them walking away a few steps. Woody and Luke exchange a worried glance.

head_text.subj: EXT. LUKE'S STREET. LATER THAT NIGHT

text: McConnell and Luke watch as Woody starts up his Corvette. McConnell has regained his composure.
Hey, Woodrow, isn't it about time  you donated this thing to a museum?
Woody revs the engine, which ROARS lustily. He grins.
Internal combustion, boys. Accept no  substitutes.
Luke laughs. Woody looks at McConnell.
Jim, if there's ever... if there's  anything Terri and I can do --
I'm okay. Really. Thanks.
Woody reaches out to shake Luke's hand.
See you when I get to Mars, Luke.  Don't solve all the mysteries of the  universe, okay? Leave a little  something for the next guys.
I'll see what I can do. Just make  sure you bring some fresh beer.
You got it.

With a final glance at McConnell, Woody slips the car int gear. McConnell and Luke watch as he drives away. A silen Luke glances at his old friend, growing more serious. We  sense he's been waiting all night for a chance to say thi
Should've been your mission, Jim.  Yours and Maggie's.
McConnell, looking after Woody's car, becomes very still.
None of us ever wanted Mars the way  you two did. Not even Woody. Twelve  years of hoping for this assignment,  training for it --
That's all over now.
If Maggie hadn't gotten sick -- if  you hadn't pulled yourself out of  the rotation to take care of her --
McConnell turns to him, his eyes flashing danger. He will not tolerate pity. Luke sees this but presses on.

No, I'm gonna say this. I have to  say it... (pause) I wanted Mars One. Hell, I battled  you for it every step of the way.  Never wanted to beat anybody so bad  in my life. But not like this...  Jim, I'd give this all up in a second,  if it would bring Maggie back to us.
McConnell is deeply moved, and for a moment doesn't trust his own voice.
I know that, Luke. You don't have to  say it... Mars is yours now. Go get  it.
(pause) Take care of yourself.
Yeah. You too.

Luke nods. They grab hands for a second, then let go. Luk walks back towards his house. McConnell watches him for a moment, then turns, walks over to his Jeep. He opens his  door, then pauses. He turns. Looks up at --
A tiny reddish dot hovers there, glowing steadily. Mars  itself, a tantalizing prize. But for him now, more distan than ever. For him, perhaps, never to be attained.
As we see these thoughts going through him. After a momen he looks down at
And the sandy verge of the front yard.
Are a map of complex emotions: regret, injured pride, inf yearning. Gently, a bit self-consciously, HE LIFTS ONE SH And sets it down again, making a careful, deliberate foot in the sandy soil...
Sequence omitted from original script.

Instantly we're hurled into an immense, stunning LANDSCAP mysterious and vivid as a fever dream. Dazzling sunlight. vast plain of rust-orange soil. Countless craters. Boulde the size of houses, tossed about by the hands of gods. Tw moons hanging in a salmon-pink sky. On the horizon, tower craggy peaks. And, at center -- the only sign of life -- small, mysterious, moving puff of dust.
Sequence omitted from original script.

CLOSER ANGLE as a small, Sojourner-like, multi-wheeled ro vehicle ambles INTO FRAME, jouncing along the orange Mart soil, pausing to snuffle its sensors towards the occasion interesting rock. Lettering on its side reads "ARES-8."
Suddenly Ares-8 pauses. Its video lens WHIRRS out, fine-t focus, as it becomes intrigued by something OFFSCREEN -- higher, more distant target. The little fellow almost qui with excitement.

A one-man ATV ROVER waits in the background, in a dry  streambed, as Luke, in an EVA spacesuit, swings a clawed  rock hammer against a multi-layered, sedimentary rock fac Reddish dust coats his bulky white suit. Despite that bul he moves easily in the light Martian gravity (1/3 Earth's A hunk of rock breaks off, and Luke examines it more clos holding it up to his clear faceplate. He's very happy,  absorbed in this work, when his RADIO CRACKLES.
Luke, you read me?
Yeah, Renee.
Luke, I just got ARES-8 on line and...  Well, we think you're gonna wanna  see this for yourself.
Luke, though reluctant to break off work, is intrigued.
Copy that.
As Luke turns away, headed for the rover
To REVEAL a STAGGERING PROSPECT, seen for the first time: Valles Marineris, that planet-creasing slash. So wide, so deep, it boggles the mind: on earth it would reach from N York to L.A.
Sequence omitted from original script.

The crew of Mars One - Kirov, Willis, and Cote -- have jo Luke, gathered around some display monitors. They're in N jumpsuits; the Hab has artificial atmosphere, enhanced  gravity, and heat. All are captivated by what they see. O

We see a low-angle image of an elongated, rubble and dirt covered MOUNTAIN. Hard to tell scale, but it looks huge.  What's most striking, however, is a WHITE PEAK barely  protruding through the rubble two-thirds of the way along the mountain's ridgeline. Its whiteness is in clear contr to the typical rust-orange of the surrounding rubble; wha more, this strange little peak also displays an oddly-smo multi-planed symmetry.
What the hell is that?
No idea, boss.
Where is it?
Cote glances at the others. They're all smirking, as if t share some secret joke Luke's not yet in on.
You don't wanna know.
C'mon, what's so funny? Gimme the  coordinates.
He leans over to read a digital gauge, but Cote covers it with her hand, enjoying the tease.
Latitude 41 degrees north, longitude  9 degrees west.
The Plains of Cydonia. So? (pause) Oh no. You're not telling me --
They all laugh as the other shoe drops. Luke's expression incredulous, exasperated.
Oui. Exactement! It's Kirov's fault,  he picked today's sector.
Hey, c'mon! We've got a scientific  duty to check that thing out.
Luke sits, taking over the Ares remote control from Cote. They all watch as he fine tunes the image, trying without success to coax more resolution.
Great. That's great. The first anomaly  we hit, and it's gotta be in the one  place guaranteed to make NASA look  ridiculous... You know how many books  have been written about that damned  mountain?
The Egyptians put it there.
No, the Amazons.
No, it was little green men!

And all because a couple of lousy  impact craters happen to look like  eye sockets. If this gets out, we'll  have every UFO kook on Earth spouting  off on the six o'clock news... C'mon,  people, gimme a read here. Is that a  cinder cone?
Nah, too smooth. Too angular. Volcanic  upwelling?
No fissures. No caldera.
It's an upwelling, for sure. But  maybe not volcanic...
The others look at him, puzzled. Luke leans in closer, wi growing excitement. He points to the screen.
Look at the color. And see how shiny  it is? I could swear that's ice...
This far south?
Impossible. You can't have ice at  this latitude. Not unless...
They look at each other, Luke's excitement now leaping fr one to another of them. They're almost trembling.
Oh my God.
How far away is it?
Sixteen kilometers northeast. Take  us twenty minutes to get there.
(considers a moment) Let's send a packet to Micker. Then  we'll go check it out.

head_text.subj: EXT. MARS ONE BASE CAMP. DAY

text: Slide back, REVEALING the crew in EVA suits, carrying gea They walk over to...
The astronauts climb in through the hatch. The last one i pulls it shut behind him and locks the latches. We see Co and Luke check their screens and press some buttons. Luke puts the rover in drive.

As the rover moves off across the rocky surface, dust kic up from the wheels, we get our first exterior glimpse of Mars One Base Camp. The main HAB UNIT looks like a huge t can with a conical top section; it connects to a separate inflated-bubble GREENHOUSE. There's also an OXYGEN STILL, PROPELLANT PLANT, and, on the other side, a couple hundre meters distant, the massive ERV (Earth Return Vehicle), w arrived as a separate, unmanned flight. Rows of SOLAR PANELS, arrayed on the ground, and an AMERI FLAG on a thin pole, about man-height, complete the scene
A vast, impressive, MULTI-SECTIONED SPACECRAFT is driftin majestically above Earth. The main hull displays both NAS and U.N. flag decals.

We MOVE IN towards another of the station's segments, whi is dedicated entirely (as we see from more labels and  insignias) to the Mars Program: Control Room, Training an Living Quarters, and a Vehicle Docking and Launch Area, w Mars Two is already positioned for its eventual flight. W hear LUKE'S EXCITED VOICE, over speakers.
This is a truly anomalous formation.  Looks like nothing we've seen so  far. The structure appears to be  crystalline, at least from the angle  displayed by ARES-8 ...
On a large CENTER DISPLAY SCREEN, we see Luke and the Mar One crew, sitting around their kitchen table in the Hab,  finishing lunch while taping this VIDEO MESSAGE.
(grins) We're all trying not to go too nuts  up here, but -- we think there's a  good chance this could be an extrusion  from some subsurface, geothermal  column of water. And if we're right...
He looks at his crew. They beam like cats who ate canarie
...then we've found the key to  permanent human colonization.
There's an EXCITED BUZZ among the assembled TECHNICIANS,  FLIGHT ENGINEERS, and SCIENTISTS. This would be a fantast epochal discovery.
Sits at the center console, wearing a headset. He's now t Mars One CAPCOM (Capsule Communicator), and his manner is brisk, efficient, all-business. A TECHNICIAN leans in for instructions.
Tell geology and hydrology we need  to scramble on this. Full-court press.
The technician nods, hurries away. McConnell, sharing the intense excitement of those around him, stares up at
Where Luke and his crew are still smiling, well knowing t excitement their bombshell will create.
Anyway, we'are going out to take a  closer look at it, try to get an  idea of its composition. (checks his watch) By the time you receive this, we  should be just about on-site.

head_text.subj: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY

text: The rover is a hundred meters away and moving fast TOWARD CAMERA. We BOOM DOWN to REVEAL Ares-8, still faithfully  holding its point, like an Irish Setter, with its video s WHIRRING OUT. The rover drives up and slows to a stop nearby. The hatch door cracks open and some dust vents out. The door opens the way and the astronauts climb out. They all look up in awe. We hear their voices ON RADIOS.
Jesus Christ...

Gleams in the sun, dazzling white, its facets as planed a smooth as if an architect had drawn them. It pierces thro the topmost rubble at the near end of the big mountain -- isolated, butte-like giant, stretching two miles from lef to right in front of them.
Walk towards the mountain. There's a very deep, very low, staccato tone intruding over their headsets.
Anyone else hear that?
Yeah. What is it?
Sounds like our antenna's out of  phase.
Can you fix it?
Hey, skip, I can fix anything.
Big talker. Renee, Sergei, let's  break out the radar, see what this  thing's made of.
As they go to their jobs, the deep, barely audible rumbli tone continues.

head_text.subj: INT. SPACE STATION. CORRIDOR OUTSIDE MMCR. DAY

text: MULTINATIONAL CREWMEMBERS walk by, in the artificial grav of the busy station, as RAY BECK, mid-50s, approaches fro the opposite direction. Beck is the tough, crewcut, PR-sa head of the NASA Mars Program (ID'd by his name tag), and just now he's leading a covey of U.N. AMBASSADORS on a to The ambassadors, of both sexes, many nations, and all rac look as excited as schoolkids.
...and this is the Mars Mission  Control Room, nicknamed "Micker." I  understand a comm packet is incoming  from Mars One Base Camp, so you may  find this interesting.
He opens the doors, ushering his flock inside.

The ambassadors enter, oohing and ahhing over the impress array of gadgetry and personnel, and especially over the screen. Some of them start taking souvenir snaphots. The  NIGERIAN AMBASSADOR turns to Beck, whispering curiously.
That man over there. He's in charge?
Who is surrounded by a KNOT OF TECHNICIANS, to whom he is giving quiet, precise instructions. They hover, then depa like so many eager bees.
Smiles indulgently at the ambassador's misunderstanding.
No, actually, that's Jim McConnell,  the CAPCOM. Our voice link to the  astronauts? Jim's been with the manned  Mars program since its inception.  One of our real pioneers.
Will he be going to Mars, too?
Ah, no. This is as close as he gets.
Luke and his crew have finished eating, and are clearing  away their dishes and leftovers.
...anyway, that's about it. We'll  send another packet when we get back.
Cote clears her throat, gives Luke a look. The others can barely conceal their grins.
Oh, right. One more thing. Today is  a very special day for a good friend  of ours, and I know he's there right  now.
McConnell looks at the screen, worried. What's Luke up to
Now, he hates it when any fuss is  made, so I won't mention his name...
A look of relief comes over McConnell.
...because the last thing in the  world I'd ever want to do is embarrass  someone like Jim McConnell.

McConnell winces -- Dear God, no -- as, on the screen, Ki appears from OFF CAMERA holding a cupcake with a burning  candle stuck in it, and the Mars One crew starts SINGING  "Happy Birthday" to him. Loudly. And very off-key.
C'mon, you Micker weasels, sing!
Soon most everyone in MMCR is singing along -- even some the jolly ambassadors -- with the noticeable exception of Beck, who stiffens unhappily. McConnell is mortified.
(sings a line, then,  to CAMERA:) Hey, Ray! Take a look at him! Is he  all red with one of those fake "I'm- a-good-sport" grins?
Beck looks over at McConnell, who indeed is red in the fa with a fake "I'm-a-good-sport" grin.
And hey, you guys, check out Ray!  Does he have on one of his "This- wasn't-in-my-mission-plan" faces?
Indeed, Beck's smile is thin, sour, disapproving.
Nothing you can do about it, Ray!  We're a hundred million miles away!
Luke and the crew finish singing the song. Luke raises th cupcake in a toast.
Happy Birthday, Jimbo! Make a wish!
He and his crew lean in, blow out the candle. They laugh applaud, then wave goodbye.
Catch you again soon. Take care,  buddy. End of transmission.

Luke reaches out, turns OFF the CAMERA, and the display s GOES BLACK. Beck turns, his gaze locking with McConnell's. He's annoy as if this violation of protocol were somehow McConnell's fault. McConnell returns his stare coolly.

head_text.subj: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY

text: Cote stands by a display screen mounted on the rover. Kir has a big radar gun on a tripod, pointing at the mountain Luke turns to Cote.
Well? What's under there?
(puzzled) Je ne sais pas. I... I think there's  something wrong with the equipment.
What?
I mean, it can't be right. It says...  it says there's metal under there.
Luke doesn't understand. He walks up to look at the displ screen.
(points) There's ten, twelve meters of rubble  and sand, and then... solid metal.
That doesn't make any sense. You're  reading a vein of ore.
(shakes her head) No. It's under the whole mountain.
The deep pulsing tone continues. Luke frowns.
Nick, could the problem with the  antenna be interfering?
Could be.
(to Cote and Kirov) Try it closer and up the power. I'll  watch the screen.
McConnell is taping an audio message to be sent to Mars a the rest of MMCR looks on. Beck is gone. So are the U. N. ambassadors.

Ah, we're all pretty stoked about  that formation you spotted, Mars  One. The folks in the geology and  hydrology back rooms are going over  your images and comparing them to  every photomap they've got.

head_text.subj: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY

text: Cote and Kirov are close to the foot of the mountain,  resetting the radar gun on its tripod. The deep vibrating tone continues. Luke is some distance away, by the rover. He looks at Wil who's still working on the rover's antenna.
Nick, how we coming on that antenna?
Goin' as fast as I can, boss.
Cote and Kirov are having some trouble with the switches the radar gun. They turn towards Luke and Willis.
Hey, Nick. Come show me how stupid I  am. I can't get this to work.
Willis looks at Luke. Luke nods -- Go help them. Willis s towards the radar gun.
McConnell is handed a slip of paper, glances at it.
Medical wants me to remind you that  you're three days late on your blood  tests. I know they're a bore, but  you've got to get them done, or  else... or else I don't know what.  Just do them, okay?

head_text.subj: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY

text: Willis, Cote, and Kirov get the radar gun up and running.
All set here, chief.
Luke sidles over to the display screen on the rover.
Okay. Crank up the juice and let's  see what's in this sucker.
McConnell checks over his clipboard list of updates.
I think that's about it for business.  But on a personal note, be advised  that, ah, none of you can sing worth  a damn.
LAUGHTER in the MMCR.

head_text.subj: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY

text: Luke watches the screen on the rover, as, by the mound...

Flips a switch on the radar gun, then swivels its muzzle  slowly across the near slope of the mountain. We hear and feel the radar signal. The immediate result is that the  pulsing tone we've been hearing suddenly stops.
Looks up from the display screen. A puzzled expression.
Why did that stop?
A split-second later, he gets his answer. We hear a WHOOS a mighty rushing of wind, as
Starts to swirl and rise, straight up from the top or the mountain, at its center. As it swirls, the cylinder picks debris -- pebbles, sand -- from the sediment-encrusted su of the slopes.
Stare up at this spectacle, awed. A cyclone? Some kind of energy wave? They have no idea. At the moment they're too fascinated to even be scared.

We see the whirling cylinder rise, higher and higher,  perfectly straight, until in just moments it's as tall as skyscraper. As it rises, it gains speed and power, narrow at its top into a conical vortex. It's sucking up so much dirt, so many rocks -- even small boulders now -- that th accumulating debris begins to darken its swirling, transl outer "skin".
Exchange amazed glances. Can't believe their eyes...
McConnell still hovers by the microphone.
Honestly, Luke, if you guys don't  have anything better to do with your  time, I can make some suggestions to  mission medical. There are worse  things than blood tests.
LAUGHTER and GROANS from the staff in MMCR.

head_text.subj: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY

text: Luke, still staring in fascination, becomes aware of sand and pebbles flashing past his helmet. From behind. He tur
As the nearby landscape BLURS. The vacuuming effect is  becoming more general across the area. More violent.

And the spell is broken. He keys his throat mike, his lip moving, but no sound can be heard over the ROARING WIND. waves his arms, motioning for the others to back away, to the rover. Wind whips at their EVA suits as they obey him retreating. Luke, backing away himself, is afraid to take his eyes of the cylinder. Then he sees that one man -- Willis -- hasn't moved. In f he's busily snapping photographs of the cylinder. Luke hu over to him, tugs his sleeve.
But still stares up, transfixed, like a man face to face  with a cobra. Luke follows the young astronaut's frighten gaze, and his own eyes widen as he sees

Beginning to tilt down, then coil sideways. Suddenly they looking into the huge open "mouth" of it, as sand and roc fly into the swirling darkness... The monstrous, gaping maw slithers down over the rim of t mountain, turning this way, then that. Seeking them. And  then, with horrifying precision, it locks in on the littl group of astronauts. And lunges towards them...

head_text.subj: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY

text: Luke and Willis turn, running as hard as they can towards the rover. But the suction is so great, it's as if they'r held back by wires. The ground itself is SHAKING, RUMBLING, as earthquakes be to open fissures across the plain. The ROAR of the vortex the GROANING of the earth, are like an onrushing freight  train...

In the maelstrom of flying debris, they can barely make o Cote and Kirov, still retreating, leaning back with all t strength against the suction, while staring up, aghast. Suddenly a hurtling rock, the size of a basketball, smash into Cote's helmet from behind, crushing it and killing h instantly. Blood sprays into the wind, immediately  crystallizing, in the sub-zero atmosphere, into red pelle

head_text.subj: LUKE, HORRIFIED, FLINGS HIS ARM UP

text: As bloody hail patters against his faceplate and forearm. instant later he sees
Snatched up by the wind, then swept past him, in a terrif blur, arms and legs flailing, mouth open in a silent scre as he vanishes...

Abruptly opens, and he slides into a fissure. Scrabbling  frantically with his gloved hands, he manages to momentar arrest his fall, gripping the edge of the fault line, wit his helmet and one elbow thrust over its lip. The air is  almost solidly choked with debris, deadly boulders bound  over him, and torrents of cascading sand are burying him  alive...
Barely conscious, as he watches, for a horrifying final  instant, as...
Is sucked bodily into the black maw of the vortex, spinni and tumbling like a rag doll...
His features grotesquely distorted by the forces tearing him, before suddenly his faceplate is sprayed with blood, and...

Willis's spacesuit explodes, his entire body disintegrati into a million bits, which instantly disappear into the  hellish maelstrom. And then that maelstrom itself, just a abruptly... STOPS. Vanishes. There is an instant, ringing SILENCE, as awesome in its o way as the roaring storm itself had been...

On the plain, as the last pebbles, released from suction, pitter down, bouncing. Swirls of dust and sand drift away settling gently. The harsh orange landscape is once again calm, peaceful. And then, from the direction of the nearby mountain, we h another sound: the deep bass pulsing rumble returns.
As McConnell finishes his message to Luke.

Oh, and I talked to Debra. She and  Bobby are doing fine. Said to tell  you, they're, ah, they're on their  "third time through the book, page -- (glances at a note) -- page 125." They send their love  and say take care of yourself. Same  from us here, buddy. Till next time,  then. End of transmission.

head_text.subj: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY

text: MOVING ANGLE, the CAMERA EXPLORING ground zero, as the ba pulsing rumble continues... WE PASS the Rover, canted sideways into a little crater,  with its canopy missing, one axle fractured, but miraculo still with all four wheels... WE PASS faithful little ARES-8, lying on its side, partia crushed under a boulder. It gives a final, pitiful WHINE, its video snout slowly extending, then dies. And finally come to the area where the fissure had been, and see

head_text.subj: THE FISSURE HAS BEEN FILLED IN

text: Leaving only a slender crease of umber sand. No sign of L The pulsing rumble continues, over, as we see

An extraordinary sight, seen from high in the air, lookin back down. Staring up at us from the bottom of a shallow  crater, scoured clean of its aeons of accumulated silt an rubble, is a structure resembling a vast humanoid Face. The surface is gleaming white, apparently metallic. The  features are suggested by intricately interlocking planes slopes, ramps. The "eyes" -- hatches of some kind? -- are closed, and the overall expression is eerily calm, but  terrible in its power, like some ancient tribal mask. We see the Face clearly for only a few beats before thick scudding clouds OBSCURE it, but the deep, pulsing rumble  continues, low and insistent...

We're inside the Mars Two spacecraft, which is still in i docked position alongside the Space Station. Woody Blake, wearing a NASA jumpsuit, floats up into the  cockpit in Zero-G, studying a thick manual.
(reads) "Problem: Hatch door malfunction,  backup power fail, manual override  fail. Solution: Replace circuit  breaker 907B."
He straps into the pilot's seat, staring at an electrical junction box at one end of the console.
Okay... Piece of cake.
He swings open the housing, revealing a bewildering tangl of fuses and wires. He sighs heavily, as Terri drifts up  beside him, also in a jumpsuit, and straps into the co-pi seat.
God, who dreams up these nightmares?
Don't try to change the subject.
I'm not! We're talking about your  sister's wedding, right?
Very funny. We're talking about  dancing lessons. Before my sister's  wedding.
Honey, do you mind? I've got a  catastrophic power failure here.
He peers into the housing with exaggerated concern. But  Terri's not so easily sidetracked.
Woody, we're a married couple. Would  it kill you to invite me out on the  floor once in awhile?
I danced with you at our wedding.
I'm not talking about shuffling your  feet around while you grab my butt.  I mean real dancing. Cha-cha, rhumba,  jitterbug --
Face it, honey, some couples dance,  some go to Mars. That's life.
I'm serious. We've got two more months  in this training rotation, but just  as soon as we get home, we're starting  lessons. If we never dance, people  will think there's something wrong.
If they see me dance, they'll know  there's something wrong.
Reaching past him, she pulls out the required breaker. As reacts, surprised, she smiles, despite her exasperation.
You are such a lug.
Overhead, an intercom CRACKLES. We hear PHIL.
Cockpit, this is Control.
Control, this is Cockpit.
Uh, Terri, they want us all back in  the Station. Report to Micker.
Who says report to Micker?
The little men who live in my head.
Phil, c'mon! We just started this  drill.
Woody, it was Ray Beck. He told me  to round up the team. Now.
Woody and Terri exchange a worried look. What's wrong?
Sequence omitted from original script.

A crisis atmosphere prevails. The big room is more crowde than we've ever seen it, with ENGINEERS and MANAGERS hurr by, huddling in tense, conferring knots, or muttering  feverishly into microphones. On the center screen, a giant image of Mars. A frantic fl of green numbers crawls above and below this, and the sit of the Mars One Base Camp is marked in blinking red.
Are staring up at this screen, appalled. McConnell and Be stand nearby, briefing them.

Then, at 1417, the X-band continuous  data stream from Mars went silent.  All data -- med, environmental,  everything -- suddenly stopped. While  we were trying to figure out what  the hell went wrong, we got a signal  from the folks at the Large Array at  Soccoro.
At the same moment we lost the data  stream, they picked up an intense  burst of energy from Mars.
What do you mean, "intense"?
(hesitates) Catastrophic.
Looks are exchanged among the Mars Two crew.
What about the crew?
The level of energy in the pulse...  didn't seem survivable.
What about the REMO? It went into  Mars orbit last week. Maybe that  could give us some clue.
Good thinking, Woody. That's just  what we tried next.
He leans over, punches buttons on a keyboard.

An orange dot can be seen in its orbital ellipse around M leaving a glowing electronic trail. This dot gets isolate in a viewing box, then enlarged and rotated into the comp animated image of a small, ugly, industrial-looking unman cargo craft, labelled "REMO."

The Resupply Module checked out fine.  No instrument failures, no change in  status. Orbit holding steady. But  there was something else. The REMO'S  computer contained an uplink message --  a very faint, highly distorted  transmission from Mars One Base Camp.
Someone's alive.
Yes.
How?
The message is almost indecipherable.  Two teams are still working on it.  You better see for yourselves.
FINGERS press buttons on a console. McConnell, Woody, Ter and Phil are crowded around a monitor with Beck and two w TECHNICIANS.
Still concentrating on the audio. We  managed to bring out a couple more  words, but we've got a long way to  go.
Show us whatever you've got.
The technician nods, then gestures to his assistant who h a play button.

Black for a moment, then static. Out of this static comes faint image of Luke, sitting alone at the Hab kitchen tab He looks awful -- dried blood on his face, bloodshot eyes The image is blurry, heavily streaked, and most of what h says is lost in waves of static.
...make this quick... may be only ch-- (long section of static) ...to the site, when we... hit us  just as we... --thers are all dead...
Woody, Terri and Phil look at each other -- Oh, God.

(following more static) ...low sound that we couldn't  understand. Then all of a sudden  there was this terrib... (another long burst  of static) ...--stems are holding up for now,  but I don't know how long I can...
The monitor screen GOES BLACK.
That's it.
Woody and his crew stare at the screen, stunned. This is catastrophe almost too huge to grasp.
As Beck leads McConnell and the other shaken astronauts d a corridor, Phil pauses, seeing...
At her desk. TWO CO-WORKERS are trying to comfort her. On of these women looks up, and her reddened eyes meet...
He looks back at her, haunted.
What did Luke mean by a "low sound?"
In an otherwise empty lounge, the astronauts clutch Styro coffee cups. Beck stands nearby. Through a large viewport behind them, stars glitter against the inky blackness.
If this was a earthquake, as we're  now assuming, there's usually an  auditory component.
But that energy pulse they picked up  in New Mexico...
Electromagnetic emission. Not uncommon  with large-scale geophysical  phenomena.
(incredulous) Causing this kind of damage? I don't  buy it. We're missing something here.
McConnell and Woody exchange a glance... Woody's right.
Luke must be in pretty bad shape if  he hasn't blasted out of there in  the Earth Return Vehicle. That thing's  designed so even one crew member  could fly it back to Earth.
Even if Luke was in great shape, he  couldn't get home. That energy pulse  would've fried the ERV'S computers.
Other than the computers, how do we  think the ERV fared?
Well, so far our modelling says it  should be in pretty good shape.
Which means it's gonna be up to us  to get new motherboards, drives, and  software to Mars. As fast as we can.
McConnell looks at him, nods. They're on the same wavelen But Beck is more cautious.
Whoa, slow down. It's gonna take us  weeks just to analyze this data.
Right, but meanwhile, we've gotta be  working up a mission plan.
Luke needs us now.
Luke may already be dead. And even  if he's not, it's doubtful he's going  to be able to transmit again. So we  wouldn't know whether it's safe to  land until you were almost there.
What about SIMA?
Terri looks at Phil -- SIMA?
The Saturn Imaging Probe. It's going  to slingshot around Mars on its way  through the solar system. It could  be retasked to take pictures, read  radiation levels at Mars One Base  Camp.
Good idea Phil. If SIMA tells us  Luke hasn't survived and it's not  safe to land, we swing around Mars  and come right back home.
Yes. We can design the mission to  have a free return capability. It's  a long trip, but if you don't land  it's the best option.
We're getting ahead of ourselves.  You're forgetting the bigger problem. (they look at him) The orbits are all wrong. Our first  decent launch window is almost eight  months from now.
But we can go earlier and get there  faster if we reconfigure the payload  for extra fuel. We've modelled that,  Ray. I've modelled it.
On paper, yeah. But those stresses  have never been tested in space.
The ship can take it.
I wasn't thinking of just the ship.
A tense beat. Again we sense the test of wills between th two tough-minded men, once good friends.
I know the protocols for a Mars  Recovery Mission better than anybody,  because I helped design them. And  I'm saying these guys can do it.
He's right, Ray. We've got a real  shot.
A pause with beck weighing the odds. He looks at Woody.
Give me an updated mission plan by  0800 tomorrow. Then I'll put it in  the works.
You'll have it by 0600.
He looks at Woody, Phil and Terri, who are just as eager.
Let's get to work.
McConnell exits followed by Terri and Phil, but as Beck s out, too, Woody stops him.
Chief, could I have a word?
Beck looks at him a moment, nods.
Sequence omitted from original script.
In a quiet corner, Woody and Beck are alone.
I've no longer got the right crew.
(surprised) What do you mean? Bjornstrom can be  up here on the next shuttle.
Bjornstrom is a geologist. He's good,  but not for this. My people just  lost eight months of training. This  is a different mission, with a  different objective.
I haven't been given authorization  for a mission yet.
But when you are, it ought to be  given the best chance for success. I  want McConnell to fly right seat.
Beck's expression hardens.
He's no longer on mission status.
Yeah. Because you washed him out.
He washed himself out. He only had  to pass a few more psych evaluations,  but he refused to take them.
Ray, he's the best pilot I ever saw,  and you've got him benched at a desk.
Everybody has to pass the psych  prelims. No exceptions. Jim knew  that.
Maggie was his wife. He didn't want  to lie on a couch and share her with  strangers.
That was his call. But I had to make  one too. It was tough as hell, but  I'd do it again.
His wife wasted away in front of his  eyes. What was he supposed to do?  Suck it up? Get with the program?  What was his crime? That he was upset?  That he cried...?
I couldn't trust him!
Beck and Woody stare at each other. A long tense beat.

(his voice softer) Not in a crisis... I'm sorry Woody,  but Jim lost his edge. Are you gonna  stand there and tell me Jim McConnell  is the same man he was two years  ago? You want me to bet four more  lives on that?
This stops Woody, just for a beat. Then makes him press o harder, with even greater intensity.

When Maggie died, yeah, it knocked  the shit out of him. It knocked the  hell out of all of us. But you know  and I know that he's still the best  we've got. He and Maggie wrote the  book on Mars. He's got more hours in  the sims than the rest of us put  together. Ray, we can do this. Give  me McConnell as co-pilot, and we  will bring Luke home. And that's a  promise.
Beck looks back at him, his features taunt.
Woody, Terri, and Phil stand at the edge of the big contr room, waiting and watching, in a tense silence, as

Beck and McConnell are huddled together at the CAPCOM's  console. Other personnel have moved away, giving them roo Both men are seated, leaning forward, with McConnell list intently, while Beck does most of the talking, very quiet After a moment McConnell looks up in surprise. His eyes s the room till they find
Woody looks back at him, nods: C'mon, man. Take it.

Is a study in conflicting emotions. But after a moment he masters his feelings, turns back toward Beck. A few more  quiet words are exchanged, then Beck offers his hand.  McConnell hesitates, then shakes it. Both men rise, and  McConnell turns again to look towards
Who react with relief, glad that he's now a part of their crew. Woody grins, giving him a thumb's up.
As he smiles. Then he starts towards them, with a new ene in his step, a new sense of confidence and purpose. And a he WALKS TOWARDS US, PASSING OUT OF FRAME...
Sequence omitted from original script.

head_text.subj: EXT. DEEP SPACE. MARS RECOVERY. DAY

text: An infinite canopy of stars. After a moment, some of them begin to be BLOTTED OUT as
Glides INTO VIEW. "MARS RECOVERY" (formerly Mars Two) loo much like its sister craft on Mars: a conical cockpit mou above a "tuna can" crew Hab module.

The entire lower deck forms a segmented section of the hu that rotates on bearings to provide artificial gravity; w see window ports spinning past, then an American flag emb Behind this lower deck, in an extending network of struts like the abdomen of a dragonfly, are the three huge round PROPELLANT TANKS. Then vast, delicate-looking rectangular SOLAR PANELS, which sweep out to either side of the ship; these also bear the dish of the earth-pointing HI-GAIN  ANTENNA. And finally comes the great mass of the ENGINE B housed within a curving AEROSHELL; three hatches in the  aeroshell can open to allow the main thrusters to fire th for a mid-course burn.
To the forward section of the ship, APPROACHING a viewpor in the EVA airlock chamber. Inside, we can see Phil leani forward, concentrating on some task...
Sequence omitted from original script.

location: EVA AIRLOCK. DAY. A BUNCH OF M

text: Are floating in mid-air, forming an intricate 3D pattern. the EVA airlock, it's zero G. Phil, strapped into a chair by a galley counter, is just  completing this weightless puzzle by placing a final blue M&M. He looks bored, sluggish. In the b.g., Terri is hunc over a microscope. McConnell emerges from the core tunnel, behind them, comi up from the lower Hab, then pushes off from the ladder,  floating towards Phil. He grins, admiring Phil's obsessiv handiwork.
What's that?
That... is the exact chemical  composition of my ideal woman.
Used to be.
He plucks out a couple of the M&Ms as he drifts by.
Hey!
McConnell grins, snacking on the M&Ms.
Now what is it?
Phil looks sadly at his floating model.
A frog.
McConnell and Terri laugh as Phil starts scarfing down th rest of the M&Ms. Swooping at them with both hands.
I guess now we have our answer to  the effects of long-term  interplanetary travel on the human  mind. The answer is Phil.
(smiles) I'm gonna get an update on SIMA. It  should be just about close enough to  start capturing some surface images.
He's drifted to another short ladder, and now grabs it, s up to the cockpit, atop the Hab.
As McConnell appears in the cockpit, he sees Woody by the forward instrumentation panel, looking at a monitor. The  cockpit is also zero G.
Hey, Skip.
Take a look.
McConnell pulls himself forward.
MARS completely fills the screen. Surface details are cle visible. Something is moving down there, an amorphous bro swirl.
What do you make of that?
Dust storm. Southern hemisphere,  coming from the east... Big fella,  too.
Headed for Chryse Planitia.
Yup. Could get a little hairy just  about landing time...
McConnell pulls back from the screen, looks at Woody.
We'll have to be ready to move fast.  Maybe even advance our ETA. Those  things can cover the whole planet,  and last up to a year.
A beat. They both hope he's wrong.
When does SIMA do her fly-by?
Tomorrow morning, about 0600. That's  when we find out whether we came all  this way for nothing.
They exchange a glance. Woody's right, but the thought is too terrible to dwell on. McConnell looks back at Mars.
(softly) My money's on Luke.

head_text.subj: INT. MARS RECOVERY. EVA AIRLOCK. NEXT MORNING

text: Just turning over to read "0545."

Pulls her gaze away from these numbers. Judging from her  redrimmed eyes, it's been a long, anxious night. Restless looking to distract herself, she reaches for a test tube blood, straps it into a centrifuge, sets it spinning. Nea is her electron microscope.
Lies on his cot in his own cubicle, with the door closed. The lower hab has artificial gravity (AG) and McConnell c move normally. Hands behind his head, he stares at his bu
Rests there, in its leather travel frame. Beautiful, smil dark-haired: MAGGIE MCCONNELL. Her face glows with  intelligence and energy.
Shifts his eyes. The clock on his bulkhead reads "0546."

Stands in the communal bathroom, still in his pajamas, a  towel around his shoulders, brushing his teeth. He glance at another digital clock, which reads "0547." Shakes his  head impatiently. He looks back into the mirror, then is  surprised to hear MUSIC lilting incongruously over the  loudspeakers: Elvis Presley's "Blue Moon."
Sequence omitted from original script.
Phil floats in through the connecting tunnel, then stops  himself at a handhold. He grins, charmed by the sight of

Like a weightless Fred and Ginger. Woody is surprisingly  good at this. Enthusiastic, unselfconscious. He sweeps Terri gallantly about the little cabin, pushing off from every handy surface, even guiding her into some  passable twirls and dips. She laughs, shaking her head.
What brought this on?
Zero-G. My last chance to be graceful.  Once we're in Mars gravity, it's  back to shuffling my feet and grabbing  her butt.
I'll take what I can get.
She grins, kisses his ear, as Phil turns, sees

Who has now arrived, is also watching the dancing couple. twinge of sadness crosses his features. But when his eyes meet Phil's, he shakes off the feeling and manages a smil Aren't they something? Over the music, they hear a CHIRP from the SHIP'S COMPUTE then an announcement.
Attention. Incoming packet.
They all look at each other. This is it! Woody spins over a console, shuts off the music.
It's SIMA.
The crew is gathered around a display screen. The lights dim, reflecting up off their faces. By their expressions, can tell the news is not good.
It's a color, high-resolution satellite image of the Mars One Base Camp. Ghostly, dust-covered. No signs of life.
Looks deserted.
It's still standing, though. So is  the ERV. And look, there's the  greenhouse.
We know Luke survived for at least a  few hours. Question is, are there  any signs of recent activity?
They all scan the screen. Phil spots something.
There.
He grabs a stylus and touches the screen. They all look.
Using where the stylus touches the screen as the focal po the image enlarges. THREE LONGISH DIRT PILES appear, some fifty meters from the hab.
What the hell are those?
McConnell gets it first.
Graves.
They all realize he's right. They sit back, stunned. But  then Phil has another thought.
Hold on. There's only three. That  means --
Phil --
It means Luke must still be --
No. It just means there was nobody  left to bury him.
This quiets everyone for a long moment.
Check the radiation levels.
Phil keys in some commands and data pops up onscreen.
Normal.
Go to the disaster site.

Phil uses the stylus to bring MORE IMAGES into view. The  frame moves over the terrain in the direction of the Face first in SWIFT BLURS, then slowing. Scattered rock debris come into view. The IMAGE ARRIVES where the mountain was, and they see... Debris in every direction, NEAT SPIRALS of it now, droppe uncannily into place, like some massive earth sculpture. if - but this makes no sense -- it had been swirled towar a LARGE CRATER. The crater itself is a perfect circle. Th FOCUS on the CENTER OF THE CRATER, but the image gets  distorted by STATIC.
What's wrong?
I don't know. Magnetic interference?
Phil tweaks the stylus, but the image won't clear up.
Go to infrared.
Phil works the keyboard.
Goes to INFRARED, reading heat, The middle of the IMAGE,  where the Face is, is still distorted, refusing focus.
Sit back, exasperated.
Must be a problem with SIMA. I don't  see how an earthquake, six months  ago, could give us this kind of  distortion.
That was no quake.
He leans closer, staring intently.
Then what the hell was it?
McConnell shakes his head. But his every sense is engaged he's like a predator just sighting his prey for the first time. We see in his eyes an utter determination to unlock this secret.
Mars Recovery is speeding ever closer to Mars, which now  looms large, a dusty red mysterious sphere.

head_text.subj: INT. MARS RECOVERY. LOWER HAB. DAY

text: McConnell and crew are eating dinner while they watch a t message from MMCR.
As Ray Beck addresses them. Other NASA STAFFERS, twenty o more, have crowded in behind him, and we sense their grea hopefulness and high spirits; the whole team's triumph is tantalizingly close now.

We're going to continue analyzing  this data and try to determine what  the problem is with those images.  Frankly, we're just as stumped as  you guys, but we'll keep on it. (glancing around) We agree that the evidence of the  graves is inconclusive and that a  ground search is advisable. Be aware  there are little sand storms kicking  up near Mars One Base, but the big  one you spotted is turning south. It  shouldn't be a factor.
Beck takes a breath, smiles.

We're all pretty excited here and  we're sure you must be feeling the  same. Enjoy your meal and get a good  night's sleep. We anticipate that  tomorrow morning you will be Go for  Mars Orbital Insertion.

head_text.subj: INT. MARS RECOVERY. LOWER HAB. DAY

text: WHOOPS OF JOY from McConnell's crew. Woody and Terri high five each other.
God bless you and goodnight. End of  transmission.
The monitor screen GOES BLACK.

head_text.subj: INT. MARS RECOVERY. LOWER HAB. NIGHT

text: The lighting is subdued for a sleep period, but everyone' too restless. There's a low HUM of equipment.

Terri and Phil are playing computer Monopoly under a sing light. Terri is using touch-screen technology to move her piece. She glances at Phil. He has spread some M&Ms out,  letting them drift in mid-air as he performs his ritual  weeding out of the red ones. She shakes her head.
What if you opened up your meal packs  and found that, instead of putting  in everything but red ones, they'd  made a mistake and put in only red  ones?
Hey, that's a funny notion. And what  if in your meal packs, instead of  brown rice, there were spring-loaded  spikes that shot into your eyes?
(pause) How did you ever pass the psych  evaluation?
When you're schizophrenic, they take  the higher score.
He touches the screen to roll the dice.

head_text.subj: INT. MARS RECOVERY. LOWER HAB. NIGHT

text: McConnell, in his cubicle, looks away from the photo of  Maggie. Haunted by memories. He rises, flips through the in a storage case, pulls one out. He holds this carefully hesitating, then feeds it into his computer. Immediately screen saver vanishes and we see

An impromptu celebration, a bunch of friends gathered in semi-darkened living room. The footage is HANDHELD, a bit jerky. People have paper plates of food, beers in hand,  everyone is a little tipsy. Debra is there, Terri, Phil,  Cote, Kirov, others. They're watching a STILL PHOTO SEQUE shown on a large screen TV, with commentary by Luke and W
Is of a small boy (YOUNG MCCONNELL) in his pajamas, kneel in front of a Christmas tree. He's grinning ecstatically he holds up a brand new model rocket.
Jim's first ship was seriously  underpowered...
LAUGHTER at this. Some AD LIB CRACKS about the painfully haircut and the pajamas.
Is of a gawky-looking teenage girl (YOUNG MAGGIE), standi on a porch at night, posing a bit self-consciously by a  telescope on its tripod.
Maggie was always starstruck...

More LAUGHTER, plus some digs about the nerdy eyeglasses braces. VIDEOCAMERA swings around the room, REVEALING the adult JIM and MAGGIE. They sit side by side on the hearth leaning into each other, looking very happy.
I'll get you guys for this.
More LAUGHTER. Everyone's having a great time. The VIDEOC swings back towards the TV screen as
Jim and Maggie, young adults, standing on the wing of a  fighter jet. Both in Air Force flight suits, helmets in h Suntanned, cocky, flashing radiant smiles.
When they met at the Air Force  Academy, it was "love at first  flight."
GROANS and LAUGHTER from the offscreen watchers.
After that, NASA training was tough.  All Jim could think about was  exploring a heavenly body. More ribald  LAUGHTER, as
Maggie and Jim, tethered together, floating weightlessly space suits.
But Maggie, as you can see, kept him  on a short leash. Until...
Shows McConnell, in a dress uniform, leaning in to kiss  Maggie, who wears a white bridal gown.
Mission accomplished!
As he smiles at this, hearing the renewed LAUGHTER and CH the AD-LIBBED DIGS from the video. He becomes aware he's alone. He looks up.
Stands in the doorway of his cubicle. Their eyes meet. Th both smile, turning back to the video. Remembering.
Luke and Woody have stepped forward, INTO SHOT, standing the sides of the TV, where the last photo lingers. Luke w his hands, hushing everybody.
Today we celebrate a new chapter in  their story. And guys, it's a pretty  historic one.
Both men raise champagne flutes.
Let's hear it for the newly-announced  Captain and Co-Captain of Mars One.  To Jim and Maggie!
CHEERS at this, repeats of "Jim and Maggie!" Luke grins,  giving a little signal, and we see

Of Maggie in Jim's arms, both of them in goofy tropical  vacation wear, smiling. Evidently a photo taken in the su somewhere, but here it's been crudely superimposed onto a Martian landscape. Laughter greets this unlikely image.
When you guys land, it'll prove once  and for all there's no intelligent  life on Mars.
More hoots of LAUGHTER, CATCALLS, but Maggie jumps in to  protest, as the VIDEOCAMERA SWINGS TO HER AND JIM. Terri  sits nearby.
Hey, c'mon, what if I'm right?
Oh no, here we go! Don't get her  started! Somebody put on some music!
It's our sister planet!
Oh brother!
LAUGHTER at this, and Maggie joins in. She's a good sport
Maggie, why does this have to be  about us? Mars is a great opportunity  for pure science.

We'll do the science. And we'll do  it very well. That's what we've  trained for. But what if there's  more...? In all our myths, in every  human culture, Mars has always held  a special attraction. What if that  means something? Only we don't  understand it yet...
The mood of the party is changing, as everyone is caught in Maggie's spell. She has a radiant simplicity. The VIDE CAMERA DRIFTS IN ON HER; we are caught up, too.
The universe is not chaos. It's  connection. Life reaches out for  life...
She looks at McConnell, smiles. He takes her hand.
This is what we were born for, isn't  it? To stand on a new world, and  look beyond it to the next one. It's  who we are.
A silence; the guests are enchanted by the purity of her  passion. She smiles, suddenly self-conscious. She hadn't  meant to get so carried away.
Reaches out, gently taps the keyboard, FREEZING the scree He and Woody, their eyes shining, stare at her image. A b
You okay?
Yeah. I'm good to go.
Woody glances at him. It's true. Rather than being sadden McConnell seems to have taken on new strength. A renewed  sense of wonder.
After all these years... Can you  believe it? Tomorrow we'll be standing  on Mars.
Woody nods, smiles.
You know what? She may have been  right.
McConnell looks at him.
If that wasn't a quake down there,  then something else caused it. Or  planned it... You're thinking the  same thing.
It's never been out of my mind.
Jesus. You realize what this means?
McConnell nods. Looks again at Maggie's face on the scree
She knew, Woody. She was the only  one of us that ever thought there  might be something down there.
Yeah, and we're not leaving until we  find out... Deal?

McConnell nods. They clasp hands briefly. Deal. Then Wood turns. Before leaving, he hesitates just a moment, turnin back. One last thought, and he doesn't know he's going to say it until it comes out.
Maggie was the best of us.
McConnell looks at him, silent but grateful. Woody goes.  McConnell turns back, looking at her smiling face, frozen the screen.
As seen through the cockpit windows. Huge, beautiful, MUC CLOSER now. We can make out swirling pink clouds, large  surface features. It's just before Martian dawn, the next morning.
Range 6783 and closing. 35 minutes  till Mars Orbital Capture.
Okay, people let's look sharp. If we  overshoot, there's no coming back.
Yeah, and drifting through eternity  will ruin your whole day.
In the cockpit, Woody and McConnell are in the pilot and pilot's wearing space suits but not yet helmets. AS CAMER PULLS BACK AND AWAY, we see them making instrument adjust in preparation for MOI.
Delta V systems initialized.
Charge primary APU.
Engaged. Charged.
Select HPU fuel cells for run.
Engaged.
Tie main bus to systems.
Power ready.
Select H2/O2 HPU and fuel cells for  open.
H2/O2 control valves open.
...Where Phil and Terri sit side by side at a pair of  computers, relaying cockpit commands to the systems.
Charge flow.
Charged and on-line
Reset PW.
Set
Transfer protocol data from EVA  station.
Transferred. Awaiting track  confirmation.

There's a sudden LOUD, BRITTLE POP from somewhere overhea and Phil's gloved hand, hovering over a computer screen, punctured through and through. The screen itself is holed and spiderwebbed with a loud CRACK!
Uhhh!

As he and Terri stare at it, dumbfounded. Thick droplets blood leak out and begin to swirl away, sucked up towards the venting puncture in the hull over head. The astronaut helmets dangle up there, awaiting use.
What in God's --
Suddenly we hear HIGH PITCHED ALARMS SOUNDING, then the  PINGING OF MORE TINY MISSILES, slashing across the ship's outer skin.
Are staring back from the cockpit, reacting in astonishme to Phil's drifting blood and to the alarms. Then Woody  suddenly understands.
Micrometeoroids
(scanning sensors) Breach hits in the hull!
As she seizes his wounded hand, tries to stop the bleedin He's staring at a gauge.
Outgassing! Losing pressure!
Woody, seal the breech!
As he unbuckles, dives from the cockpit back down into th EVA, and floats quickly over to a storage hatch. He yanks this open pulling out a
Then spins around in zero-G, as his eyes track
Which give a telltale hint of the puncture's location,  somewhere up among the dangling helmets on the "ceiling."

Rising to this area, and shoves aside a helmet with a  shattered faceplate -- its label reads "MCCONNELL" -- to  REVEAL A BREECH IN THE HULL. Jagged metal edges, dangling insulation. The blood droplets are whirling out through h going into the vacuum of space. Quickly Woody stuffs the muzzle of the patch gun into the puncture, firing a thick grey sealant. We hear MORE PINGS ECHOING LOUDLY, but after a few seconds they DIMINISH, th abruptly STOP. The KLAXONS continue to wail.
Kill those alarms!

McConnell punches buttons, MUTING THE ALARMS, and they al strain to listen, faces tense and sweating. A long beat. the meteor shower has passed by, as abruptly as it appear The astronauts turn, becoming aware of a strange phenomen

Have stopped in place, wobbling eerily as perfect spheres the zero-G. Then suddenly they start moving again, faster and faster, in a new direction. Down through the open cor tunnel that leads to the lower Hab.
Stares at a gauge that confirms what's happening.
Still outgassing in the lower Hab!  There must be another hole down there,  even bigger.
Losing pressure fast! We're gonna  decompress!
Computer, how long until zero  atmosphere?
(after a beat) Four minutes, nine seconds.
If we get below 20% atmosphere, the  power will shut down!
Are you sure?
Positive! A vacuum inside the ship  would cause a total electrical  failure. The nav computers will fry!
(to Woody) We'll lose all control. We won't be  able to fire the engines to capture  Mars orbit.
Just then a computer screen flickers, freezes. Phil punch keys with his good hand. What he sees shocks him.
It's already starting. The primary L- 1 hub has been smashed. The systems  are crashing.
Woody looks back at his crew, struggling to project more  calm than he really feels.
Everybody switch to suit oxygen. We  beat this in the simulator, we can  do it here. Jim, you've got the ship.  I'm going EVA.
They stare at him, stunned by their immense task.
C'mon, people, let's go! Let's work  the problem!
Terri, now helmeted, is putting Woody's helmet on him, bu something's in the way, chafing his neck. He reaches into his suit, pulls out...
From around his neck, with his little Flash Gordon rocket dangling.

As they share a brief, loving glance, but there's no time for words. She tightens his helmet ring, and he brushes h gloved fingertips on her faceplate. Then he hurries towar the inner hatch door, where McConnell is throwing airlock switches. Woody and McConnell exchange a look. At the EVA computer panel, Phil is shutting down non-esse power drains, trying to get the main computer system back line. His wounded hand makes this difficult and painful.
Jesus, it's still bleeding.
Keep the pressure on!
Eighty percent atmosphere...
The outer airlock door is now open, revealing stars, as W drifts through it into space. He's now wearing the MMU, a oversized jet pack like the ones used by the shuttle  astronauts.
With its shattered faceplate -- now useless -- drifts pas Terri as she is wrapping med tape around gauze pads on Ph glove.
Floats up to them, checking on Phil's work at the compute
Jim, you've gotta get your spare  helmet from storage.
No time. Phil, can you keep the nav  computers on-line?
I can't get this damn machine to re- initialize! And the automated systems  just went down. We can't shut down  the hab rotation from here.
I'll do it from below.
We're losing pressure. You could  embolize.
Seventy percent atmosphere...
McConnell looks at her, knows she's right. But he starts anyway. Phil reaches out his good hand.
Jim, I've got an idea. If you guys  can save enough atmosphere, I'll  disconnect the power in the main  computer bay, then jump start the  systems. I'll do a hard boot.
This is a radical, incredibly risky notion. McConnell sta hard at Phil. So does Terri.
Has that ever been tested?
Are you kidding? These machines are  much too valuable.
McConnell looks from Terri to Phil. It's life and death.
Do it.
Then he turns, and the CAMERA FOLLOWS MCCONNELL as he pus away from the console and dives down into the core tunnel heading towards the
Sequence omitted from original script.

...where he emerges from the core into the rotating Hab d and pushes himself down a ladder toward the floor. He  accelerates as he gets closer to the floor, then rights  himself with a twist and lands on his feet -- now in grav
Woody, in the MMU, is hovering over the lower segment of Hab hull, and right away we see his problem. He can't rea the damaged spot because it's spinning past him, spewing  vapor.
(over radio) Jim, how we doin' on the AG?
McConnell runs to a computer terminal and starts clicking with the mouse.
Just one goddamn second. Come on,  c'mon...
Voice print identification.
McConnell!
(a beat) Accepted. Shutting down artificial  gravitational rotation.
McConnell hears a sound up at the core tunnel. He turns,  it's Terri. She holds an small 0-2 cannister, marked with red cross.
Hang on!
McConnell grabs onto a counter edge as...
Attitude control thrusters on the hull begin firing in pu The rotation of the lower Hab deck immediately starts to  slow down. The great red ball of Mars drifts by.
Terri, lurching, grabs a ladder strut, and watches from t tunnel as...

Is also jarred by the firing of the thrusters. The rotati slows until the Hab is still. Zero-G. McConnell floats. H and Terri can hear the terrifying sound of air whistling into space through the breach hole.
Sixty per cent atmosphere...
Get some light on the hole so I can  locate it.
I've got a better idea. (shouts to Terri) Stay there!
He starts rooting through Phil's storage area -- bags of  M&Ms, comic books -- looking for what he needs.

Phil is now strapped into the pilot's seat. He's scared,  sweating hard, but concentrating fiercely as his one good hand works a battery-powered screwdriver. He's removing the panel of the main computer bay. Over th intercom, he can hear the merciless struggle going on  elsewhere.
I'm topside, Jim, do you know which  sector?
I'm workin' on it!
The lower Hab deck is no longer revolving. Woody pops his thrusters and drifts over the metallic skin. But there's  such a vast area to search!
Jesus, uh, OK, this is gonna be like  searching for a needle in a haystack.

McConnell locates a can of Dr. Pepper, shakes this violen then tosses it up to Terri, who's still in the tunnel mou She catches the drifting can, confused. When McConnell sp again, he's gasping for air.
Shake out the liquid.
Jim, I don't --
Shake it out near the hull!

Terri shakes out soda from the open can. She and McConnel watch the brown stream of fluid swirl up into the air, ca by escaping oxygen. It rises towards the "ceiling" of the outer hull, like a miniature tornado.
Sequence omitted from original script.
Woody still drifts over the hull, searching intently as h frustration builds.
C'mon, c'mon, where are you...?
Fifty per cent atmosphere...
Terri, staring at the ceiling, sees something remarkable.
Swirling ever tighter, has formed a whirlpool that's now  being sucked out through the breach hole in the hull. She can now see the ugly puncture for the first time.
(gasping) Woody, the breech is in sector four!  Sector four, copy that?
Copy, I' heading there now.
Terri turns, excited by McConnell's triumph; she's just i time to see him collapse to the floor below her, as he st to lose consciousness. He's deathly pale.
Woody spots a tiny geyser of brownish ice crystals spouti out of the hull of the lower Hab. It's some distance away from him, but clearly visible.
(to himself, marveling) Sonofabitch. You never did that in  the simulator.

Terri pushes off from the ladder, drifting weightlessly d to McConnell. She opens the valve of the oxygen cannister pushing the plastic mask over McConnell's face. He sucks air, color returning to his skin as he revives.
An incredible tangle of tubes, wires, chips, as Phil's gl fingers -- both hands now -- probe desperately through th
Where are you, you little bastard,  where are you...?

As he moves his hands and forearms deep inside the comput bay. Around him, several of the smaller screens and gauge are starting to malfunction, the data streams breaking ap streaking into electronic snow. He shoots a tense glance
Which is flickering crazily. It shows the ship moving muc closer to its critical MOI point, indicated by a flashing red triangle aimed down at the Martian surface.
Forty percent atmosphere...

Woody, popping his thrusters, moves as fast as he can tow the protruding finger of crystal, but he's not there yet. All of a sudden Woody's thrusters cut out. The ship is mo by, a meter beneath him. Woody punches his arm controls.  Nothing. Then just as the outer edge of the hab starts to pass him the thrusters kick back in. Woody grabs the edge, starts move to the hole. Woody lets out a breath.
(to himself) Whoa.

McConnell, holding his breath, grabs a patch gun from a  storage locker. Terri's still got the 0-2 cannister. He n to her, and together they push off from the floor, leapin weightlessly up to the other side of the Hab, the "ceilin They reach the gaping puncture, which they now see has be only partially dammed by the soda ice.
As Phil's gloved fingers finally locate the plug he's bee searching for. He hopes. And grip it firmly.
Gotcha!

Says a silent prayer. Then he yanks the plug. SHRILL WHIN ELECTRONIC CRACKLES from all around him, as the systems a abruptly shut down, in a way they were never meant to be  mishandled. Terrifyingly, a couple of the monitors arc to each other as they die. Dodging sparks, Phil stares at
As it also flickers and dies. Now they're flying blind.
Thirty percent atmosphere...
Woody arrives at the ice finger, knocks away the big crys then pulls his patch equipment from a pouch.

In the Hab, Terri uses the base of the 0-2 cannister to s away the interior ice chunk, then McConnell, who's gettin wobbly again, blasts the hole with the epoxy gun. As he w Terri gives him another hit of air.
Twenty percent atmosphere...
The lights flicker out in the Hab.
Outside, Woody slaps a big square patch over the hole, ri off the backing.
As it changes color and shrinks, drawing itself down into the metal of the hull.
As Phil's fingers re-connect the same plug.
From inside the computer bay. He's trembling, sweat-strea inside his faceplate. Blood has soaked through his gauze  pads. His good hand hovers over the red main power switch The moment of truth.
OK... OK now...
With a dramatic click, he throws the switch, hard-booting the computer system back on. He stares at the screens. Nothing happens!
Come on. Come on...!
Frightened, furious, Phil bangs on the switch with his  cordless screwdriver. When all else fails, hit something.
Feeble starlight from the viewports. McConnell and Terri, drifting side by side, stare at one another, expecting to die within seconds. It feels like an agonizing eternity.
Twenty percent atmosphere...
McConnell's eyes widen, as he realizes this is the same a the last reading.
Pressure stabilizing... Atmosphere  level increasing.

Terri and McConnell look at each other. Tears of relief i her eyes. He is exhausted, nearly spent, but manages a gr She holds the 0-2 mask up to his face, and as he grips it breathing deeply, they hug one another.
The lights and computer screens are flickering back on. A of them! The cockpit lights up like a Christmas tree. Phi bounces up and down like a madman, babbling in triumph.
Yes! Awriiiight! Had it all the way.  Yes!
Forgetting his injury, he pounds his gloved fist on the  console in triumph.
Shit!
He wrings his injured hand, then his gaze is caught by
Which pops back on, showing the ship and the MOI point co perilously close together.
As he keys his mike urgently.
Get back in here, guys!
Woody floats above the repaired hole, scanning the nearby surface of the hull.
Jim, there's a lot of scarring...  I'd better check for other punctures  while I'm out here.
Negative, negative. Woody, get back  inside. We've gotta start the  checklist for orbital insertion.
(a beat; reluctantly) Copy, I'm heading there now.
Woody jets back towards the open EVA hatch. But as he rea this, about to re-enter the ship, he's captured momentari by a breathtakingly beautiful sight below him.

As the huge planet is REVEALED in all its red, unearthly  glory. It's so close now that individual features can be  seen with the naked eye -- the vast chasm of Valles Marin and then Olympus Mons, poking all the way up through the  Martian atmosphere. A stunning, alluring spectacle.
Stares down at Mars, enthralled, as sunlight floods the s of the spaceship, sparkles off his visor. Dawn, after a v long night indeed. He whispers lovingly, under his breath
Hey, Beautiful...

Then he stirs himself out of his reverie and hurries thro the EVA hatch. CAMERA DRIFTS QUICKLY BACK and down along the hull as sta sunlight flares off the big propellant tanks, three in a  row, and the thick silver tubes that join them. There's a good deal of scarring and denting from the meteor shower. Then, as the ship begins to MOVE OUT OF FRAME...
On one of these tubes, a feeder line to the engine bells, see a scatter of tiny, undetected holes, about the size o the eraser at the end of a pencil. So small, so apparentl harmless...
Sequence omitted from original script.
