As Woody enters, stripped from the MMU, dripping with swe McConnell is waiting for him. For a moment the two men ju look at each other, then they surge forward into a fierce hug.
(whispers) Know what? You've got enough left.

McConnell looks at him, understands. Terri sits nearby, where she has just finished stitching Phil's hand. As Woody goes to her, she rises from her sea and looks at him tears of relief and pride in her eyes.
Piece of cake?
Well. Easier than the cha-cha.
He scoops her into his arms; they kiss passionately. Phil is blinking; something seems to be getting into his eyes. His voice catches for a moment.
I don't know what you're getting so  cocky about. We scored better times  in the sim at least twice.
(grins) How's his hand?
Terri separates from Woody, looks down at Phil.
Seems OK. Couple of the tendons are  going to be a little tight for awhile.  Try to close your fingers, Phil,  nice and slowly.
Phil starts curling up his fingers. The middle digit rema extended in the universal gesture. They all consider this for a moment. Then Phil looks up cheerfully.
Well, at least I'll still be able to  drive.
After a split-second they get it, and the whole crew roar with LAUGHTER, which builds and builds; they're almost gi with the relief of the tension...

Sails INTO VIEW, with small attitude thrusters firing as great ship maneuvers into position for its orbital-captur burn. Mars looks very large, blood-red. The entire specta is majestic, awe-inspiring.
OK, we're ready to light this candle.  Go/No Go for braking burn and MOI.  Engines?
All four astronauts are strapped in, fully suited and  helmeted. Mars looms through the cockpit windows. The  atmosphere is electric with excitement.
Go.
Systems.
Go.
Nav.
Go.
We are Go for the burn. I'm fueling  the engines.
He flips three switches, in rapid sequence, and...

As we MOVE IN on the damaged fuel line, we see a tiny but steady spray of fuel venting from the hole caused by the  meterorite. This freezes into eerie streamers and chunks, which slowly drift away from the ship. They're quite  beautiful.
Optimum angle of entry minus seven  degrees. Six... Five...
Woody looks at the others for moment -- everyone is set,  looking good -- then reaches for a last switch.
Four... Three...
Woody hesitates, then glances at McConnell.
Jim?
McConnell, moved by this honor, nods. He reaches out to t the switch himself.
Let's go to Mars.
As the countdown indicator reaches "0000.00.00", a final  signal PINGS, and he flips the switch.
In total silence, the engines ignite. The second they do, the streamers of frozen fuel explode in a white flash.
With alarms sounding, the four astronauts are slammed  violently forward, against their restraints.
What the --
Shut down engines!
He and Woody both reach out, straining against the incred G-forces, and manage to grab a red emergency lever, yanki it down hard.

Too late! IN SLOW MOTION, we see a terrifyingly violent c reaction. The fuel tanks themselves explode, one after  another. The supporting metal struts are vaporized. The s panels are snapped off. Two of the huge engine bells are  smashed sideways, out of alignment, while the third, trai pieces of the cowling, goes hurtling off, PAST CAMERA, li a flaming cannon ball. The entire aft section of the ship including much of the lower Hab, instantly becomes a shre charred tangle of metal, and even worse, the explosion ca what's left of the ship -- mainly the EVA chamber and coc to tumble end over end, cartwheeling down towards Mars.
In the windows, Mars goes crazily in and out of view. The astronauts, flung this way, then that, are all fighting  against unconsciousness.
Engines negative! No response! I've  got no attitude control!
Manual separation! Blow the bolts!
Negative! The CM doesn't have enough  thrust to correct this rotation!
We're too steep! Falling into the  atmosphere...!

From further away, the charred remainder of the ship can seen spinning down towards Mars, which now fills the scre looming as large as Earth, when seen from the space shutt The ship's motion is mercifully slowing as it hits the ou atmosphere, but just as clearly this steep, unplanned ang of entry dooms it.
Christ, at this angle we'll burn up!
Their ANGLE OF ENTRY is shown -- much too direct -- with indicated swerve into blinking red disaster. Warnings fla
How much time've we got?
I don't know! Three minutes? I don't  know!
McConnell's mind is racing furiously, desperately.
Where's the REMO?
The Resupply Module? Why? That's not --
Where is it?!
Phil punches buttons. ON THE SCREEN a second ellipse appe a blinking orange dot labelled "REMO." It appears to be s intersecting with their own trajectory.
Uh, it's close...
Damn it, how close?!
(shaken) I-I don't know. It'll take time...
We don't have time! Figure it out!  Now!
Phil frantically types in commands on the computer.
Jim, we're dead stick, there's no  way to maneuver this ship into a  link-up!
Not the ship. Just us. We have to go  EVA.
They look at him, stunned. Leave the ship?
You want us to transfer in suits?
Jesus, Jim -- if we don't make it --  if we miss the REMO...
There's no other choice! Phil, how  close?!
One kilometer, that's the best I can  do!
They stare at Woody. We feel the full, terrible weight of his responsibility. Four lives hang on his call.
Prepare to abandon ship.
Sequence omitted from original script.

The astronauts are outside the ship, tethered to each oth with long shock cords. Other cords, clipped to their suit trail gear bags. Phil clutches a silver metallic case -- precious computer repair kit. Woody is in the MMU. They'r all rotating at the same speed as the ship behind them.
On my mark, seven percent left  thruster. Three, two, one, fire.

All four astronauts fire a brief, simultaneous burst from the tiny attitude control thrusters in their suits. This  stops their rotation, bringing their travel under control The ship continues spinning in the background. Woody takes a final look at the charred, doomed Mars Reco The only home they've known for six months. He exchanges silent glance with the others. They all expect to be dead the next few minutes. Woody takes a breath, nods.
Okay. Let's go.
He pops the big thrusters on the MMU and starts heading a from the ship. The cord between Woody and the others pull taut and they start to follow.
Of Woody leading them away from the crippled spaceship,  against the magnificent backdrop of the blood-red planet  below. Four tiny figures, all alone in space.
As Phil looks back, his eyes searching the stars.
What're you looking for?
(softly, sadly) Earth.
(beat) Hey. When we get back? We really  will have to try this in the sim.
He tries to smile. So does she.
How we doin' on fuel, Woody?
Woody eyes a small display screen on his forearm.
I'm at fifty percent. (looking down) But I don't see the REMO.
Everyone is looking back at the curve of Mars against bla space, expecting to see the REMO coming up behind them.
Happens to glance directly below.
There she is!
The black outline of the little cargo craft drifts agains the red of Mars.
Jesus. She's not where I thought  she'd be.
We're going to miss her.
Looks again at his display screen, frustrated.
What do you think?
We can't catch it. Not like this.
(thinking quickly) Use the tether.
From a compartment on the side of the MMU, Woody pulls ou
About the size of a large flare gun. There's a carabiner- like hook five inches in diameter on the front of the gun
We'll only have one, maybe two shots  before she's out of reach.
It'll be better if I leave you the  gun while I run out to the REMO.  I've got enough fuel left for that.
You'll be going too fast.
I'll aim to overshoot, then brake  like hell; arc it in.

McConnell looks at him. They both know how risky this is, and they also know it's their only chance. Woody flips a  switch on the gun and pulls on the hook. Off it comes,  trailing wire. Woody clips the hook to the MMU, then hand McConnell the gun.
Seeya in a few.
McConnell nods. Woody and Terri exchange a look -- tender loving -- then Woody turns around and fires the MMU jets full throttle. As Woody pulls away, line unspools from th tether gun.

Woody is chasing the REMO from above. It's as if he were an airplane, trying to land on a car racing along a freew Woody is picking up speed quickly. Maybe too quickly. He  checks his armpad display screen.
Okay. I'm on path to overshoot. I'm  gonna take the edge off.
Woody starts braking with the MMU thrusters as hard as he can.
Glowing with orange flame. They suddenly cut off.
Show alarm. He checks his display.
I'm out. Coming in hot. Still long. (beat) Abandoning the unit. I'll brake with  suit jets.
Woody hits some buttons and the MMU's latches snap open. grabs the hook connected to the tether line, then pushes  himself free of the MMU, starts firing his small suit jet
He's still going very quickly.
Floating close together. The tether line is still unspool from the gun. They watch Woody, below and ahead of them, he races towards the REMO. Terri's heart is in her throat
Oh Jesus. Jesus...
McConnell reaches a glove out, touching her arm.
Still speeding towards the REMO. His suit jets cut out.
Suit jets gone. But I'm gonna make  contact...
Stare at Woody's distant figure.
At what velocity?
Impact's gonna be a little rough.
At what velocity?
(beat) Thirty-two.
A look between McConnell and Terri; her face is stricken.
I'm gonna use the gun to slow you.
No! You slow me and I'll fall short.
It's too fast, Woody.
No choice. I'll be okay. Here we  go...
Woody's coming down on the module at over thirty kilomete an hour. He holds the hook out in front of him with one h while grabbing the tether line with the other, and WHAM! he crashes into the REMO.
Slams the hook against a receiver on the hull of the REMO
Tries to hold onto the tether line but his momentum is to much.
Are ripped from the line.
Slides over the hull of the REMO.
Grasp in vain for something to grab onto. They drag and b and then finally his fingers close on... empty space.
Is past the REMO, freefalling toward Mars.

head_text.subj: BACK ON MCCONNELL, TERRI AND PHIL

text: As Terri screams.
Woody!!
McConnell hits a button on the tether gun and starts to r them quickly in towards the REMO.
Tries his suit jets again -- they're empty.
Falling away from the REMO.
Are being reeled towards the REMO by the tether line. Ano couple hundred meters to go.
Woody, what's your status?
(after a beat) Uh, well, no suit jets and I'm still  carrying a good deal of velocity.
As soon as we get hooked up, I'll  come get you.
(after a beat) Uh, I'd have to say negative on that,  Jim.
Negative on the transmission?
No, I heard you. Negative on the  maneuver. I am not retrievable.
McConnell and Terri share a quick, anguished look.
Woody, that's not possible. You're  not going that fast.
It comes down to the amount of fuel,  honey. The suit jets were designed  for attitude control, not travel.  Retrieval just won't work.
It has to work!
Hey, believe me, I don't like it any  more than you do.
Woody --
Run the numbers, Jim.
I am.
McConnell finishes looking over the numbers on his displa pad. Terri is staring at him. When McConnell's eyes meet  hers, they are red-rimmed. Haunted.
Woody, you hang tight. We'll get  into the REMO, fire her up, drop her  into a lower orbit and come scoop  you up.
Sounds good, Jim.
It's gonna take half an hour to get  the REMO reoriented! Woody'll be...  He'll be in the atmosphere by then!
Then we'll have to get her moving  faster.
We don't have time!
You listen to Jim, honey. It's a  good plan.
No! We are going to --
Oh Jesus, look! The ship!
Phil points. McConnell and Terri look.
Is now several kilometers below and behind them. It's glo red... then orange... then white. Then it erupts into a g fireball, devoured by friction with Mars' atmosphere.

head_text.subj: MCCONNELL, TERRI AND PHIL IN DEEP SPACE

text: Are all staring at this, awed, when McConnell happens to  look up again. He sees something alarming.
Look out!
They are drifting quickly into the REMO.
Brakes!
Fire their suit jets, slowing themselves down. They bang  into the REMO at about one-tenth the speed Woody did. The find handholds and grab on. McConnell hits a button on th tether gun.
Releases from the REMO's hull. McConnell hits another but and it is reeled all the way into the gun. Phil is alread scrabbling at a latch on the REMO's outer airlock door.
Okay, let's get inside! Phil, start  dumping the cargo, or there won't be  room for us.
But we need those supplies for --
Dump the cargo. Hang on, Woody!
Is looking back at the REMO. Smiles with relief to see th Terri has reached it safely.
Will do, Jim.
He turns to look at...
Right below him, filling his field of view. A long beat.
(softly) Hey, Beautiful...
Terri makes a snap decision. She grabs the tether gun fro McConnell's surprised hands, then pushes off from the REM McConnell lunges after her, his gloved hand straining.
Terri, no!
But it's too late. She's already out of reach, and now fi her suit jets, pulling quickly away from the REMO.
Is reaching to activate his own jets, when
Grabs at his wrist, restraining this suicidal courage. Th stare at each other. McConnell wrenches his hand free, ha maddened, agonized, staring after Terri.
Goddammit, Terri, it won't work!
But Terri keeps on going.
Looks back at the REMO, as he continues to fall towards M Sees the small figure of his wife heading towards him.
Terri, what are you doing?
I'll tell you what I'm not doing,  Woody. I'm not going to watch you  die.
Terri --
You'd do the same for me.
Phil is watching as Terri drops towards the distant twink of Woody's suit lights. The airlock door hangs open. Phil looks at McConnell, anguished.
Get inside. Dump the cargo, then  start the systems. (Phil hesitates) Now.
As Woody keys his mike. Tries to steady his voice.
No. I wouldn't come for you. Not if  it just wasn't possible.
I can do it!
No, Terri, you can't! You don't have  enough fuel to get me, stop us both,  and get us back. Hell, you come any  farther and you won't have enough to  get back yourself.
No response from Terri.
Listen to me, goddammit! You have to  stop! You have to stop now!
He's right, Terri... It's no use.
Terri looks at her armpad display.
As her fuel indicator drops from 50 percent to 49 to...
Releases her thumb from the toggle control.
Stop firing.
Drifts, staring towards Woody.
Are on the same trajectory, going the same speed, and onl about a hundred meters apart. But it might as well be  infinity.
Okay, honey...? You gotta go back  now.
The hell I do.
Terri raises up the tether gun and pulls the trigger.
Comes shooting out of the gun, wire spooling out behind i
Watches as it comes shooting down toward him.
Woody gets larger and larger, the hook gets closer and cl and then SNAP! -- the hook stops. ANGLE ON THE TETHER GUN The wire has run all the way out.
Looks at the drifting hook, ten agonizing meters away fro him. His only life preserver.
Hits the button and the wire starts winching fast back in the gun.
What are you doing?
I'm gonna jet a little closer and  try again.
Terri, you spend any fuel getting  closer, you won't get back, and if  anyone tries to get you, they'll die  too.
No response from Terri.
Is whipping back toward Terri and the gun. Woody's voice  cracks; he's very close to tears. Pleading now.
Honey, please go back. Go back and  help everyone get down to the surface.
The hook slams back against the muzzle of the gun. Terri  resets the gun quickly, in an anguished fury.
I am not losing you.
I can't let you do it. I can't. I'm  sorry.
Looks at Woody, two hundred meters away, sensing somethin different in his voice now, a terrible resolve...
Woody...?
Raises his hands to his helmet ring. His eyes shining.
I love you, Terri. God how I love  you.
He unscrews the ring, pops the seal. The outrush of air p his helmet all the way off. Woody shuts his eyes and open his mouth.
Woody, nooooooo...!!!
Ice crystals bloom with Woody's last breath. There's noth to suck in. He doesn't fight it. He lets death come.
Tears streaming, chest heaving, frantic.
Woody, oh Woody, please God, no!
Hovers over her suit jet toggle control. McConnell's voic from the distance, sounds very tired. Like he's aged fift years in the blink of an eye.
Come back, Terri.
Terri's thumb is still poised. Death would be better.
Outside the REMO. The hatch is still open. We see Phil in staring out anxiously towards Terri.
(quietly, simply) He's gone.
He sees no movement from the distant, small figure of Ter
Please, Terri... (long beat) We need you.
Pushes the toggle control... to one side, not forward.
Inside her helmet, is streaming with tears. She turns her around, reluctantly. Heads slowly back towards the REMO.

head_text.subj: INT. INTERNATIONAL SPACE STATION. MMCR. DAY

text: On the big screen at MMCR, a glowing green icon labelled  "MARS RECOVERY" is shown in orbit, as a stream of compute figures crawls beside it.
Beck stands by the NEW CAPCOM, as the latter repeats head data.
Okay, they're Go for the burn and  MOI. Should be initiating the burn  just about... now.

Suddenly the data stream goes crazy. It shivers, streaks, breaks up... then stops. The blinking green icon represen Mars Recovery glows brighter... then vanishes. A moment of stunned silence in the big room. Then a risin babble of scared, confused voices.
Takes a step forward, staring helplessly at the screen. H face goes pale, stricken. His worst nightmare is taking p right before his eyes -- and for the second mission in a  row...
The REMO is now on the night side of Mars. Cargo boxes,  packing cases and assorted equipment containers float out The hatch is sealed.

McConnell hovers by a bulkhead. He's anguished, haunted b the image of Woody's death. We see him struggling to over his grief and shock, trying to force himself to concentra on the critical tasks at hand. In front of him, a panel h been opened; he's facing
Already glowing, surrounded by coded switches, indicator  lights, com ports.
Stares at these, thinking hard, remembering. He's holding palm-sized computer, already wired into this panel. He be tapping the keys, but then stops himself. Reconsiders. He turns, looking back at

Hunched on what would be the floor if the REMO were on la They grip stowage straps to keep from drifting. Clearly t tiny, rude cargo craft was never designed for manned  operation. It's claustrophobic, bitterly cold.
Is a map of torment. He is shivering, both from cold and  fear, barely holding himself together. He hugs his comput supply case like a scared child would hug a teddy bear.
Is worse. A thousand-yard stare. She's in shock.
Knows he has to occupy them. Speaks softly.
Phil? (no response) Hey, Phil...?
Phil looks up at him dully.
We're going in blind. We'll deploy  the chutes by laptop. I need to get  on the data bus, put in a software  patch, and try to soften this tin  can's landing. I could use your help  with the patch.

After a moment Phil releases his strap, pushes towards  McConnell. He stares numbly at the monitor for a few beat then takes the little computer from McConnell. He begins tap the keys, slowly at first, but then with more confide
That's great. Good job. (turning to Terri) Hey, Terri, I was wondering. Think  maybe we could rig some kind of  seatbelts out of those cargo straps?
Terri hesitates a moment, then looks at the strap in her  hand, as if she's never seen it before. Dully she reaches for another one, begins looping them together.
Studies both of their faces intently. Knows that he can't push them too hard, too fast. They're moving like robots, but at least they're moving.
Small thrusters are firing, getting the REMO into positio for entry into the atmosphere. Then all the jets fire in unison, braking the REMO, as it falls away from us, towards Mars at night.
The astronauts, restrained on the floor by Terri's jury-r strap system, hold on for dear life. The buffeting throug the atmosphere is shaking them violently.
We see the effect of the incredible g-forces: faces disto unable to focus their eyes. Each of them thinking, once a Now I'm going to die...
Sequence omitted from original script.

head_text.subj: EXT. MARS ONE BASE CAMP. NIGHT

text: The Mars One Base Camp looms in the foreground, like some desolate, otherwordly ghost town. And then, in the night beyond it, we see an eerie and beautiful sight: a bright  streak of red as the REMO slashes down into the Martian  atmosphere, like a shooting star, finally disappearing be distant mountains. Then all is stillness again, deathly  stillness and silence...

head_text.subj: INT. INTERNATIONAL SPACE STATION. VIEWPORT. DAY

text: Beck stands by a viewport, staring out into space. He's j lost four good friends, and also knows he is seeing, in t disaster, the probable end of the Mars Program, and the  certain end of his own career. He doesn't, at first, even hear the nearby VOICE.
Ray...? We've got some new data,  just coming in.
Beck looks up, his eyes red-rimmed. The CapCom shifts  uneasily. He's holding a computer printout.
We just -- it doesn't make any sense.  We're not sure how to read this.
Data?
Yes sir. Telemetry reports the REMO  has left its orbit and reached the  Martian surface.
(pause) Crashed?
No sir. Under power.
Beck snatches the paper, staring at it. For the first tim we see some life coming back into him.
When?
Sixty-three minutes after Mars  Recovery went off-line. Sir, the  graph reads like a controlled descent.  But that doesn't make any --
Beck suddenly understands. And it's a joy to see his face the tears of happiness that spring into his eyes.
They used the REMO as a lander.
The CapCom stares back at him, feeling the same surge of  hope.
It's McConnell, it's got to be! Nobody  else could have pulled this off. Son  of a bitch! They're alive.
Sequence omitted from original script.

head_text.subj: EXT. MARTIAN SURFACE. MARS ONE BASE CAMP. DAY

text: As we see the Mars One Base Camp: silent, very still. In distance, the massive ERV still looms, perched for takeof the bottom rungs of its ladder buried.

We see that sand has drifted high against the Hab, as wel as the sides of the partially-deflated tunnel and greenho and the four-man rover. The oxygen still and propellant p are almost buried. Solar panels, some of them punctured b micrometeors, FLAP and CREAK eerily in the slight breeze. And finally,
We see the camp's American flag, still on its toppled pol but nearly obliterated by sand.

Who are spooked by this desolation. They've paused at the edge of the camp. They have dragged along with them from their landing site crude sledge, improvised from the REMO's hatch cover and  some cargo straps. On this, their meager supplies. McConnell, glancing at the others, knows he's got to keep their spirits up. He kneels, digs out the flag pole. Brus off the sand, he rights this and re-plants it firmly in t ground, packing the sand down with his boot. He stands fo moment looking at the flag, his eyes moist. Despite the c they have made it to Mars. When he turns, Terri and Phil are looking at him, moved.
Better?
(pause) Damn right.
Terri, let's see if that oxygen still  is operational. Phil, you better  check out the ERV. I'll take the  Hab. If you find Luke's --
He catches himself. Phil and Terri look at him.
Just keep in touch.
Phil steps from the umber sand onto the ERV's ladder, beg to climb. The four-man rover is nearby, sand drifted high against its tires.
Terri kneels by the oxygen still, begins to scoop away sa with her gloved hands. She still looks numb.
(on radio) I'm at the main airlock door.
He unlatches a panel, grips the emergency lever inside, t it. After a seeming eternity, the door groans and creaks  open. Little puffs of dust and sand swirl about, settle.
Entering Hab.
Perched atop the ERV's ladder, Phil, using a battery-powe drill, is just removing the final screw from the hatch co He lifts off the heavy cover, lets it tumble to the sand.
I've got ERV access. I'm going in.  Terri, you okay?
Terri is still scooping sand. She's just cleared the firs row of gauges.
Yeah. This is gonna take awhile to  get back to 100% capacity.
McConnell walks through the kitchen, which we recognize. pauses to look at the table from which Luke and his crew  taped their final, fateful message.

Still sits there, eerily, with its stub of burned-out can Half-finished, frozen cups of coffee. Suddenly, out of th corner of his eye, he catches a flash of white. He spins, startled, and sees HIS OWN REFLECTION. In his white pressure suit, staring back at him from the  screen of a video monitor. Above this is perched the came the Mars One astronauts used for their comm packets.
This place is filled with ghosts.
Phil, in the pilot's seat of the ERV, pushes a computer's power button. The screen flickers weakly to life, startli him a bit, but all he sees on it are white streaks, crazy static.
ERV appears structurally intact.  Computers are fried, just as we  thought.
Terri has cleared more gauges, valves. She sits back on h heels, studying the tangle of pipes.
Copy that. I've got busted filters  here, clogged intakes. Helluva cleanup  job, but so far no major damage.

head_text.subj: AN INNER AIRLOCK DOOR WHOOSHES OPEN, AND MCCONNELL ENTERS

text: On a fantastic, almost jungle-like atmosphere. The plants have been allowed -- encouraged? -- to grow wildly. Some even pushing against the inflated roof. Water condenses o the leaves and the roof, then is captured and routed thro pipes of every shape and size, dripping into a clever  assortment of collection jars. Liquid water.

Reaches into a bucket, touches the water. His glove comes before his wondering eyes, dripping. Grasping the implica he looks down at his forearm instrument pad. Blinking red letters read "25 deg. C." And something else the puffy white material of his suit is starting to sligh deflate, revealing his arm's shape. There's air pressure here!
Punches in more numbers, and gets the readout: "Nitr. 78%/ 02 20%/ C02 1%/ Trace gasses 1%."

Slowly reaches up, unsealing the neck ring of his helmet. hesitates, then lifts it off. Takes a deep, quenching lun of pure air. Holds it in. Lets it slowly out. For a momen he doesn't trust his own voice. Then speaks softly toward his helmet.
I'm in the greenhouse. You better...  you better come see this for  yourselves.
Phil, still sitting at the cockpit controls, turns. Throu a side viewport he can just make out the greenhouse.
What is it?
There's no answer. He rises.
Terri rises, concerned, and turns. Through the distant,  translucent wall of the greenhouse, McConnell's shadowy f can be seen, moving slowly.
Jim...?

McConnell sets down his helmet, starts exploring, pushing through fronds as he makes his way down an aisle. The dri foliage is so dense it almost chokes his path. Everywhere looks, he has the sense of a scrounged-together, recycled jury-rigged environment, where a great deal of ingenuity come into play. He pauses, looking up... Overhead, a bellows, stitched together from pieces of pla tarp, slowly inhales and exhales, pumping air into a vent the upper deck of the Hab. Its power comes from a crude w wheel, a buckets-and-strut assemblage, tidily sutured wit duct tape, like some giant Erector set. As McConnell turns away from this, still marvelling, a ra figure leaps through the foliage! It smashes into him, wi a HARSH SCREECH, knocking him to the ground. McConnell, on his back, straddled by his attacker, fights back as best he can. A blur of flailing arms and fists, a he tries to push the creature away. Staring up, he catche glimpse of the almost unrecognizable

Whose frightened eyes glare back at him through a swaying curtain of dreadlocks. His skin is creased, weathered, ab a scraggly beard. His clothes are tattered, patched toget In one fist he grips a rock hammer, which he swings high  overhead, about to drive the claw through McConnell's sku McConnell grabs his arm desperately, trying to fend him o
Luke, it's me! Jim McConnell!
We see a flash of uncertainty in Luke's eyes. Then he yan his arm free, and his hammer arcs up even higher, tremble in the air.
You're not here!
Luke, it's Jim!
No, no, you're not... you can't be  here.
Your wife is Debra! Your son is Bobby!  You were reading Treasure Island  with him...!

As he stares down at McConnell, Luke's eyes finally light with recognition. but before he can move, he is seized fr behind and flung backwards to the ground, the hammer ripp from his grasp, as Terri and Phil pinion his arms. McConn scrambles to his feet.
Don't hurt him!

McConnell kneels beside Luke, signalling to Terri and Phi that it's okay to let him go. They stand back, pulling of their helmets. Everyone is panting, out of breath. Luke sits up, slowly studying their features, one after  another, as if still not quite certain whether they might vanish. His voice is hoarse, rusty from disuse.
Phil... Terri...
Luke looks with incomprehension at McConnell.
Jim... I don't understand. You're  not supposed to be here... Why are  you here? Where's Woody?
He didn't make it Luke.
Luke stares at McConnell, trying to absorb everything. He looks to Terri, who looks down.
Oh no.
Luke shakes his head in dismay. He seems to shrink in on  himself. It's all too much for him to take in. McConnell  kneels and puts his arm around Luke, comforting him.
Sequence omitted from original script.

head_text.subj: INT. ELSEWHERE IN THE GREENHOUSE. DAY, (MINUTES LATER)

text: Luke sits on the side of his cot, in the little tented  sleeping area he's created in one corner of the greenhous Nearby, his hotplate, pots, and some freshly harvested  vegetables and greens. The others crouch around him.
Luke, what happened here?
A flash of fear in Luke's eyes.
(whispers) We fired the radar. It came. They  all died.
What came?
They all died, but I was spared.  Why? Had to be for a reason. Then,  all of a sudden, I knew why I was  spared.
His voice drops to a conspiratorial whisper.
So somebody would be left to figure  out the secret.
He taps his forehead, significantly, then nods once or tw The others exchange an uneasy glance.
Luke, we still don't understand.
Come. Comecomecome.
He rises quickly and scuttles off, waving an impatient ha without waiting to see if they'll follow. McConnell, Terr and Phil stare after him for a long moment. Phil breaks t silence.
Is it just me? Or is he about two  mealpacks short of a picnic?
Long term exposure to low gravity  can have an adverse impact on the  brain. He could be suffering from a  form of asphyxia.
Or maybe his whole crew died and  he's been marooned alone on Mars.  Let's give him time to adjust.
McConnell and Terri follow in the direction Luke went. Ph trailing, mutters to himself.
Greatgreatgreat.

head_text.subj: EXT. MARS ONE BASE CAMP. DAY

text: Luke, now in a patched-up pressure suit and grubby-lookin helmet, stands peering down unhappily at the improvised  sledge, with its meager supplies. McConnell, Terri, and P walk up behind him, wearing their helmets again. They hea Luke over his RADIO.

So... let me be sure I understand  this. Your ship blew up, with all  its supplies. Then you emptied the  cargo out of the REMO, and it was  totalled on landing. You've got no  food, no water, no spare oxygen,  nothing but what I see here...?
McConnell and the others are silent, embarrassed. Then  McConnell nods. Luke looks at him, a cracked grin.
What kinda rescue mission is this?
That kind.
He points to the computer repair case, as Phil lifts it o a sledge. Luke turns, looks at the case, then Phil.
Check it out. New nav boards for the  ERV. I got four round-trip tickets,  baby, right in here.
(softly) Four.
In some mysterious way, this reminder of Woody's death se to bring him fully back into himself. He takes Terri by t shoulders, deeply saddened. She meets his gaze.
Terri... I'm so sorry. He was a good  man.
Thanks, Luke.
When there's time, we'll talk.
She nods, grateful. A beat. He looks at the others.
This way.
He starts off across the sand, and they follow.
They stand looking down at the three long mounds of dirt, Luke completes his account of the disaster.

...When I came to and dug myself out  of the sand, my faceplate was cracked.  Leaking badly. I barely made it back  to Base. It was weeks before I could  work up the nerve to go back out  there and look for their...
He has to pause, collect himself.
Renee was the only one I could find.  But it didn't seem right, somehow,  to dig just one grave.
There is an emotional silence. Luke turns, takes a few st He stares into the distance, observing the swirling dust  around them. McConnell hesitates, notices Luke's gaze.
Has it been blowing like this for a  while? (Luke nods) We saw a big storm from space. But  Micker said it was turning south.
Luke looks off into the distance, studies something only seems to see.
If it holds course.
McConnell pulls his gaze away from the horizon, looks at  Luke.
This -- whatever it was -- this force.  You say it came directly out of the  top of the mountain?
You don't believe me. That's okay.  But I'm not crazy, Jim.
McConnell isn't quite sure how to reply to this.
What did you mean by its "secret?"  What secret?
(pause) You better see for yourselves.
Sequence omitted from original script.
McConnell, Terri, and Phil follow Luke into the Science L area of the Hab, then stop in their tracks. Their helmets are off. It's very cold in here; their breath is frosty.

The Lab is crammed with rock and sand samples from many  locations, all tagged and labelled. There are drawings an diagrams covering the walls: Martian landscapes, annotate maps, and over and over, obsessively repeated, drawings o the vortex that destroyed the Mars One crew.
See, where they made their mistake  was, they must've planned for it to  be visible from Earth...
The others turn, looking at him. Luke is aiming an electr space heater at his computer. As the coils glow red, he r his hands together, poised over the keyboard.
Who's "they"?
Luke reacts to their blank stares. He has a kind of jitte feverish intensity, a secret excitement.

Don't you understand? Hundreds of  millions of years have gone by. You've  got erosion, sand storms, lava flows,  meteor impacts -- hell, in that much  time, the whole surface would've  changed. So no wonder we never saw  it before. Well, I mean, we saw it,  but not like they meant us too. Too  much dirt on it.
The others exchange worried glances. Is he totally nuts?
Saw what?
This.
On the computer screen they're looking at...

Pictures of the Face after the disaster, seen from ground level, in telephoto views. Rising out of a ring of rock a dirt rubble is the shiny-white profile of a gigantic face The white is smooth, impenetrable. It has the scale of a  mountain, but the planes and angles are clearly unnatural

head_text.subj: MCCONNELL, PHIL AND TERRI, (INT. MARS ONE HAB.)

text: They are stunned. Can hardly believe their eyes.
Jesus...
What is that...?
I don't know. But whatever it is,  somebody built it. And not us.
A few moments of silence while they try to absorb this.
What about the sound? That signal  you heard before the explosion?
Good, Jim, good. That's the key.
A click of the mouse and they all HEAR, over speakers, th DEEP PULSING BASS TONE.
Hear the pauses? That's what made me  realize it's a pattern -- a repeating  pattern.
Mathematical?
Luke is trembling with excitement. His words tumble out v quickly. He's been waiting so long to share this.

That's what I thought. There are  distinct blocks in the pattern, and  within each block the tones come in  groups of three. Threethreethree.  For months I struggled to analyze  it, trying different constructs...  Then I thought about dimensions.
X-Y-Z coordinates...
Right! Three groups equals three  dimensions... So I tried assigning  different graphic values to each  block, group and tone. And finally I  got... this.
He types another command. They all look at the monitor, t glow reflecting on their faces. They are amazed again.
Where we see the beautiful interlocking chain, the univer familiar double helix, of a DNA molecule -- the elegant  blueprint of life.

head_text.subj: BACK TO SCENE, (INT. MARS ONE HAB.)

text: My God... Is that what I think it  is?
DNA... that's a model of DNA!
You see it, too. Thank God. I was  afraid I was just suffering from a  form of asphyxia.
She glances at him, surprised that he overheard her earli diagnosis. But he smiles, not offended.
So, okay, so -- somebody left this  thing here, somebody -- other than  human. But what the hell is it?
My guess is, it's a signature. A  self-portrait of whatever species  created the Face.
But that DNA looks human.
No way. It's missing the last pair  of chromosomes. See?
Yeah, but it's close. Damn close.
The difference between a man and an  ape is less than three percent of  genetic material. But that three  percent gives you Mozart. Einstein.
Or Jack the Ripper.
They look at him. Then all four turn, stare again at the  slowly rotating DNA, pondering its awesome mystery.
When he finally speaks, never takes his eyes off the scre We can read in them the almost overwhelming grip this mys has on his imagination.

It's been a long day. Let's get a  couple hours sleep, then tackle this  thing when we're fresher. Phil, your  first priority will be to get the  motherboards over to the ERV.  Concentrate on getting communications  up first. (Phil nods) Soon as we've got the juice, we'll  send a packet to Micker, tell them  Luke's OK, and that... everything  else that's happened. The rest of us  will take an inventory of supplies,  see where we stand. Okay?

The others nod in weary agreement. As they start out, tow the relative warmth of the greenhouse, Terri looks at Luk at his scraggly beard and his long, lank hair. She smiles brushing some locks off his forehead.
C'mon. There's a pair of scissors in  my medkit.
Sequence omitted from original script.

head_text.subj: INT. MARS ONE HAB. ANOTHER SECTION. NEXT MORNING

text: As in the Science Area, this space has enough thin oxygen for the astronauts to remain unhelmeted. McConnell and Lu are still going through what few supplies were salvaged f the REMO. Luke pauses, rubbing the unfamiliar smoothness of his che His beard is gone, his hair neatly trimmed. McConnell enj Luke's own wonder at his transformation.
How do you feel?
Like I just got back my other three  percent.
McConnell smiles. Terri enters through the hatch, removin her helmet.
The backup generator is salvageable,  and two of the solar panels. I'm  pretty sure I can get the oxygen  still back into production, too. So  we're not in such bad shape,  considering.
Good work, Terri.
McConnell, rummaging through Phil's backpack, drops an al opened bag of M&Ms. The CANDIES scatter and bounce all ov the floor.
Look at that. Phil's idea of absolute  essentials.
Luke and Terri smile. McConnell scoops up the fallen M&Ms He slows down as he does it, looking at the scatter of li round CANDIES. Something tugging at the back of his mind.
Sequence omitted from original script.

head_text.subj: INT. MARS RECOVERY. EVA AIRLOCK. DAY

text: Phil's intricately designed M&M model of his "ideal woman floating weightlessly, as McConnell drifts past it, pluck away a couple pieces of the candy. Phil reacting, in good natured annoyance. The gap in the design left by McConnel theft...

head_text.subj: INT. MARS ONE HAB. ANOTHER SECTION. DAY

text: As he trembles with excitement. With sudden comprehension
It's not a signature.
(puzzled) What?
That noise from the Face... It's not  a signature. It's a test.
Luke and Terri stare at him.

head_text.subj: INT. MARS ONE HAB. MOMENTS LATER

text: McConnell sits in front of the computer back in the scien lab area, staring once again at the mysterious DNA model. Luke and Terri stand behind him. McConnell's energy, his certainty, is almost electrifying.
It's asking us for the right answer.  It wants us to put in the missing  pair of chromosomes.
But why?
To prove that we're human.
Terri and Luke look at each other, starting to understand
We fired radar into that thing.  Concentrated sound waves...
Which it interpreted as a wrong  answer... Yes! It's like a, a security  alarm. When it gets an incorrect  response, it defends itself.
Phil is listening in on radio. He's got panels open, wire dangling, as he works his ongoing repair. He keys his mik uneasily.
So what happens when it gets the  right answer?
As McConnell looks at Luke and Terri.

(hesitates) I don't know. But we've got to find  out. (to Luke, pointing) Can you work this the other way?  Figure out which tones would be  equivalent to the missing chromosomes?  Then dub them into your recording of  the signal?
I think so, yes.
What about the radar gun? Will it  accept that input? Can we transmit a  completed signal back to the Face?
Luke stares at him, startled by what he's implying.
Phil is also growing increasingly nervous.
Whoa, whoa, hold on, Jim. What if  you're wrong? Whoever goes out  there... I mean, what if you're wrong?  Three people have already died over  that thing.
As Luke and Terri look tensely at McConnell.
Four.
McConnell looks at her.
Terri, if we leave here without  getting some answers, they all died  in vain.
Terri shakes her head.
We just don't know enough about that --  that thing out there to take any  more chances.
What are we here for, if not to take  chances...?
His passion startles them; they've never seen him so  emotional. He points at the computer screen.

This means we're not alone. It means  we're on the brink of the greatest  discovery in mankind's history. But  we've still got to prove it. Who  knows when someone else will get  back here? Or if they ever will? You  know what Congress is like. They'll  say it's too dangerous, too much  loss of life, let's go back to  unmanned flights. We could be the  last explorers to come here for  decades. We're it, guys. (pause) We're it.
(quietly) We don't have to go out there. There's  a better way.
They look at him, surprised.
Sequence omitted from original script.

head_text.subj: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. DAY

text: The familiar, plucky little figure of ARES-8 wheels acros ocher sand, with the radar gun jury-rigged onto its back. Ares' video snout WHIRRS out, extending. The familiar bas rumble of the Face is very loud from here.
Checking video feed...

head_text.subj: INT. MARS ONE HAB. LATE DAY

text: McConnell, Terri, and Phil have gathered around Luke as h pushes buttons, and a monitor CRACKLES to life. White str then a blurry image, which he tries to enhance. Finally t image starts to sharpen.
There!
They see the familiar stark white profile of the FACE, sh from ground level, in a SLOWLY APPROACHING ANGLE...
Stare at the ominous sight. They're all more nervous than they want to show. Luke's fingers delicately work a joyst as he maneuvers the remote surveyor.
How close do we need to get?
I'm not sure. Maybe we better stop  by that boulder.

head_text.subj: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. LATE DAY

text: Ares-8 whines to a stop by a large boulder, which partial shields it from the Face, looming beyond. The radar gun  swivels, locating its target. Then stops, ready to fire.

head_text.subj: INT. MARS ONE HAB. LATE DAY

text: Luke looks at Terri, Phil, and McConnell. Phil shuts the of the box holding the new nav boards, snaps it protectiv down. He nods. Terri takes a deep breath, then she nods. Luke's hand hovers over the red firing button; a moment o awesome uncertainty and danger. He looks at McConnell, wh finally gives a nod of command. Then Luke hits the button

head_text.subj: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. LATE DAY

text: From the radar gun on Ares-8's back, a sharp, high-pitche electronic burst is emitted, pulsating like a tuning fork it's fired towards the Face. After a few seconds it stops For a moment nothing happens. Then the deep bass rumbling stops as well. The only remai sound is of WIND, stirring up dust on the Martian plains.

As suddenly a huge, curved segment of the white surface b to rise from the earth, like a gigantic hangar door, slid out of sight into an upper sheath of some kind. The movem is measured, stately, utterly silent. As the segment rise it reveals a blinding white light: the interior of the Fa No inside details can be seen.
McConnell, Luke, Terri and Phil stare at this phenomenon, awed. They're barely breathing.
Oh my God...
It worked... It worked!
Check for radiation.
Luke punches buttons, waits anxiously for a readout.
Normal. Seismic... normal. Anemometer  steady. No sign of the vortex.
I don't know what we did, but guys --  does that look to you like a hostile  gesture?
No. More like an invitation.
Or another test...
McConnell is staring at the mysterious opening. On his fa a growing look of determination.
Luke, the four-man rover. Does it  still work?
The others look at him, their expressions changing as the realize what he's implying.
Sequence omitted from original script.

head_text.subj: EXT. MARS ONE BASE CAMP. LATE DAY

text: McConnell, once again helmeted, emerges from the Hab airl Luke, Terri and Phil are coming out behind him. The wind picked up, and fine dust is blowing. They stop, staring o in astonishment towards

The entire sky has darkened from its customary salmon int purplish-black at the horizon, with bloody streaks above. The DUST STORM has turned their way; it's now sixty kilom away and closing. The main body of it reaches two thousan meters above the surface and stretches out along a thousa kilometer front.
Stare at this unholy juggernaut, alarmed. McConnell turns Luke, whose expression is grim.
How long before it hits?
An hour? Maybe less.
How bad?
A storm like that? It could go  planetary. And last a year.
McConnell stares at him.
It'll sock us in, Jim. We won't be  able to take off. If that happens,  with what few supplies we've got  left...? We'll starve to death.
McConnell turns, staring off towards the killer storm. Th others look at him with questioning gazes. He turns again There's the four-man rover, ready to go. Waiting.
Phil, how much longer to prep the  ERV?
Maybe forty-five minutes. It'll be  tight, but we can make it.
Then there's still time for us to  get out there and back.
He looks a question at Luke and Terri, one after the othe Their eyes, tense but excited, signal agreement.
Stay here. Continue the repair. If  something goes wrong, you get out of  here before that storm hits.
Go back... alone?
If we're not back in forty-five  minutes, I want you to prep and  launch. (looks at his armpad  display) That's 1950 hours.
Jim --
It's not a suggestion, it's an order.  You understand?
(reluctantly) I understand. But --
You understand what?
If you're not back by 1950, I prep  and launch.
McConnell nods, satisfied. Looks at Terri and Luke.
Let's go.
They start towards the four-man rover. Dust is swirling m thickly through the air, and the WIND IS LOUDER NOW. Phil stands watching them go, a lone, rather forlorn figure.

In a WIDE SHOT, we see the rover approaching the Face, ac the plains. The sky beyond the Face is almost black, as t storm approaches from that direction. It's marching  relentlessly across the planet, with flashes of lightning now rippling up and down its face, and even small tornado spinning off near its purple-black base...
Phil has panels off. He's reaching into the guts of the m computer, working feverishly. His repair kit is beside hi

In a HIGH SHOT, we look down across the side of the Face its vast, open doorway, out of which the bright white lig is streaming. Into this corridor of light, we see the rov arrive, slewing to a stop, throwing sand from its wheels.

Looking at the cavernous vertical gap in the side of the  Face. The opening towers to a dizzying height above us; t white light strains our eyes. The three astronauts ENTER  FRAME as we see them, from behind, staring up.
As they are stunned by the immensity of the scene, the co mystery before them. Luke and Terri look at McConnell. An moment of critical decision. He keys his mike.
Phil, do you read me?
Phil keys his own mike.
Yeah, Jim. Your signal's breaking up  a little in the storm, but I read  you.
McConnell stares into the bright opening. Bathed in its l
We're at the Face. We're gonna need  a few minutes here. Same deadline,  launch at 1950. With or without us.  Do you copy?
(pause) Copy that.
Terri and Luke exchange a tense glance.
Jim, are you sure you want to do  this?
I'm not sure of anything anymore.  But I didn't come a hundred million  miles just to turn back in the last  ten feet.

Luke smiles. The three of them stare into the portal.  McConnell, between the others, reaches out and grips each them by a gloved hand. They take a sort of collective bre Then they walk forward together, into the light.

The astronauts continue forward, each of them extending a free hand. The light is too dazzling for them to gauge distances,  textures, colors -- anything at all. They can't see walls ceiling, even a floor.
Surface seems firm and level.
Roger that. Texture is smooth.
I've got good footing and no  obstructions. Let's check our --

Behind them, there is an abrupt WHOOOSH, like a giant air sealing shut. They turn, startled and nervous. Letting go each other's hands, Luke and Terri run back the way they  came, but almost immediately are stopped by a wall of som sort. The vast hangar-type door has closed behind them.
It's solid again! We're trapped.
Don't move! Keep this orientation.
The three scared, helmeted faces seem to float in the  brightness, some twenty feet apart.
(keys his mike) Phil? Phil, can you still hear me?
Phil, saying a silent prayer, reaches over and turns on t main computer. It works! He's immensely relieved.
Computers are online! Ready to load  software. But guys -- we're losing  visibility here.
He glances out the cockpit window at the blowing dust. Th realizes that he's hearing only silence over his radio.
Guys...? Jim? Luke? Terri? Is anyone  there...?
No answer. Phil stares at his radio in dread.
Don't leave me.

McConnell is staring at his spacesuit's sleeve. He can se that the suit material is starting to deflate, revealing shape of his arm, just as it did in Luke's greenhouse. He hesitates, then begins to unscrew the sealing ring on his right glove. Terri and Luke see this.
(alarmed) Jim, what're you doing? You'll  depressurize!
I don't think so.
McConnell makes the final twist on his glove and there's hiss of rushing air.
Jim, seal it!
No. That was air going into my suit,  not out. Look at your own suits --  they're not rigid anymore. We've got  pressure in here.
Luke looks at his sleeve. McConnell's right.
Above Mars atmospheric? That's  impossible.
We're millions of miles from Earth  and we're inside a gigantic white  face. What's impossible?
Terri types on her arm keypad. She's amazed.
There's six psi in here... (taps more keys) Nitrogen and oxygen.
Otherwise known as air?
Terri nods. McConnell starts unscrewing his helmet ring.  Luke follows suit.
Hey, there may be some lethal trace  gasses I haven't picked up yet, or...  or... oh, the hell with it.

Terri starts taking off her helmet. In a few moments, all three helmets are off. They hold them, glowing softly, ag their chests, as they breathe deeply and gratefully. Air. And then, at this very moment, as if they have just passe another kind of test...

Appears through the glare, soaring up before their startl eyes. White, metallic, composed of complexly-linked bands plates, ramps. It's part of a STRUCTURE whose overall hei and breadth keep us from understanding its purpose. But t hatch opening slowly in its side, at the top of an approa ramp, is unmistakable. Radiant white light streams out fr within, forming a glowing tunnel, down towards the astron
Raising their gloves against the dazzling glow. At the en of this tunnel of light, inside the hatch frame

And slowly resolves itself into a glowing humanoid form,  which we somehow sense is female. She appears benign,  wondrous. This glowing MARTIAN -- a holograph -- regards astronauts for a few moments, then beckons to them, as if say "Enter." All her motions are both calm and calming -- precise, unhurried, gracious.

Look at each other. They're awed into silence, and still  tense, but now more out of excitement and anticipation th fear. Their eyes agree: Let's go. They walk forward slowly, carrying their helmets, up the  ramp and into the tunnel of light, following the Martian, who retreats before them. They go through the hatch and  disappear inside.

Following the Martian, they find themselves in a round, o space, defined by light, with a smooth matte-metallic flo but without apparent walls. The Martian stops, turns, facing them. The astronauts sto too, uncertain what they're meant to do. Then the Martian gestures again. A cylindrical holographic column appears, rising from the floor in front of the astronauts. Inside it, a swirl of e lights, millions of them, like cosmic fireflies...
Set down their helmets, then cautiously converge around t column, forming a loose triangle. As they stare into it, myriad lights are reflected off their own eyes and their  spacesuits.
The whirling lights resolve into images, which relate to  them the story of ancient Mars:
we do not recognize. All is peaceful, beautiful.
(softly) Is that what I think it is?
Yeah. It's Mars.
Tumbles through space towards the planet...
Oh my God.
As thousands of small rocketships lift away from the surf heading in a stream out of the solar system...
And a wall of fire and debris scours the planet. Oceans b and vaporize. Two gigantic hunks are blasted out of the  planet, spinning in flames...
Involuntarily flinch, bathed in the fiery images...
As dust storms roil across its cold, lifeless surface. Th flaming hunks of molten rock cool into twin moons.
Stare at this devastation, deeply moved.
The stream of Martian ships grows smaller and smaller as continues on its epic voyage towards a new solar system.  Then we zero in on
As it peels off and goes in another direction. Graphics s a model of what the ship contains: the familiar double he of DNA. The ship heads towards another blue planet in our solar system...
As it was then. More clouds than now, more ocean, and the landforms all wedged together.
Her voice is soft.
Earth, when it was still Pangaea.  Before the continents separated.

Makes a fiery streak through Earth's atmosphere and plung into the ocean. Instantly the image of the DNA double helix grows, fillin the entire holographic column, then it begins to spin and pulse, disintegrating into a phantasmagoric whirl of new  images...
Cry out, stunned by the strobelike power of the display a

Flash into the holographic column, swimming, growing,  crawling, leaping, flying: one-celled microscopic organis plankton, plants of all kinds, insects, then fish, dinosa birds, small mammals, larger mammals -- the entire stunni panorama of evolution, distilled into a single explosive  sequence, as the images wash over the dazzled, awestruck

Until finally the images whirl away, the holographic colu dissolves, leaving only a circle of glowing, concentric,  colored rings on the floor. The astronauts are left stari at each other across the open space where the column had  been.

Now comes forward with outstretched arms and completes th circle, taking the fourth position. McConnell is opposite her glowing form, and Terri and Luke are at either side. Martian reaches her arms out, inviting them to link hands As they do so, the Martian seems to be staring directly i McConnell's eyes.
Is in wondrous awe, his whole face radiant with joy. It's the first time we've ever seen him utterly without sadnes or reserve. Staring at the Martian, he understands.
They're us. We're them...
We're Martians...?
That's what she means.
Oh my God. The Cambrian explosion.
McConnell and Luke look at her.
Almost six hundred million years  ago, there was a sudden expansion of  life on Earth. The first multi-celled  plants and animals appeared. No one  has ever understood why...
They seeded Earth.
We hear a BELL-LIKE TONE, a single lingering high note, a simultaneously the outermost ring of the circle on the fl begins to glow brightly. It is an intense chromium yellow

Step back, startled, unlinking their hands, and look at t circle of colored rings. These shade from yellow, on the  outer rim, to a deeper yellow, then orange, then finally  reds. Inside the final, deep red ring is a circle of indi blue, about a meter across. Small points of light glitter here, like stars against a midnight sky.
Steps closer to McConnell. She has picked him out in  particular. Now she beckons for him to move inside the ci of colored rings, to stand on the indigo core.

Looks back at her, nods his understanding. For the first  time she seems to smile. Benevolence, reassurance. Then a abruptly as she first appeared, she fades away. Vanishes. Luke and Terri look at McConnell, confused. There is a su static-filled CRACKLE from their helmets, nearby on the f
(over radio) ...in, please. Can you... me?
Terri picks up her helmet, leans into its mike.
Phil, we're here! We read you.
Even through the scratchy interference, they can hear the relief in Phil's voice. And then the desperation.
Thank God! Listen, this storm is  really -- (loud static) -- few more minutes, I can't -- (more static) You've gotta get back to the ship!
And then they hear only STATIC. His signal is lost.
Phil? Phil...?
Suddenly the BELL-LIKE TONE REPEATS, at a lower register, with a more sustained note, and simultaneously, the last the yellow circles of light begins to fade, as
Begins to glow brighter. McConnell turns, looking at this new color, then looks back at Luke and Terri.
We are in a ship. This is a ship.  And the countdown has already started.
Terri looks at Luke, alarmed.
He's right.
Then let's get the hell out of here!

She scoops up Luke's helmet, tosses it to him. As he catc it, she's already starting back out, in the direction the came from, and Luke follows her. Until they both become a that McConnell isn't with them. They turn back. He's stil rooted to the spot, his gaze locked on the indigo core of the colored rings.
Jim...
McConnell doesn't turn.
Jim, we gotta go.
I'm not coming with you.
(stunned) What?
Coming back, she sees how calm he is. How certain.
What are you talking about? We've  got to get home.
That's where I'm going. Don't you  see? That's what all this is for. (McConnell gestures  at the ship around  them) You were right Terri. This is an  invitation. To follow them. To follow  them home.
He looks into their faces. Terri is trying to grasp this  idea, still incredulous. Luke has the beginning of a half smile.
I have to go. This is the mission  now. To find out who we are. Isn't  that why we came here? Like Maggie  said, "To stand on a new world and  look beyond it to the next one."
Luke nods at the memory of Maggie's words. Terri remember too. McConnell's passionate conviction is affecting them  both.
You know, when you think about it --  I wasn't even supposed to be here --  all the accidents, everything that  got us to this point, it's just...  it's just... I just know it's right.
Terri looks at Luke. Luke is smiling. He understands.
I'm okay. I know what I'm doing. But  you're running out of time. You've  gotta get back to the ERV and get  off this planet. Now please go.
Luke steps closer, looking at his old friend.
I once felt like I was taking your  turn. But now I think maybe you're  taking mine. Guess I'm a little  jealous.
They clasp hands for a moment. But in this moment is a  lifetime of camaraderie, an eternity of farewell.
Thanks for saving my life.
My pleasure.
Luke nods, deeply moved. He turns away, picking up his he as Terri comes closer, looking at McConnell, a long unspo beat. Her eyes are glistening.
I wish Woody were here to see this.  He would've wanted to go too, Jim.
Terri smiles. She is starting on the road to recovery. Sh going to be okay.
He's here, Terri. We wouldn't have  made it without him.
Terri nods. She digs into one of her suit's pockets, pull something out. She hands it to McConnell, and his fist cl around it.
Take care, Jim.
McConnell smiles. Terri smiles back at him. Then she turn picks up her helmet, and crosses to where Luke has paused looking back.
Hey, Jim...?
Yeah?
Have a great ride.
Always do.
Luke and Terri exchange a final silent farewell with him, then hurry away, into the darkness.
Looks down at what Terri gave him.
With the little Flash Gordon rocketship.
Grips this tightly as he looks up.
Sequence omitted from original script.

head_text.subj: EXT. MARS. THE FACE. PLAINS OF CYDONIA. NIGHT

text: The hanger-like hatch has reopened, and Luke and Terri,  helmeted again, emerge from the Face. The leading edge of the dust storm is upon them. They can't see much more tha few meters. As they reach the rover, they hear, even in this chaos, t the deep pulsing tone of the Face has started again. They look at each other, uncertain what this means. But McConn is now beyond their help. Luke keys his mike.
Phil? Phil, do you read? (to Terri) He's not reading.
I can barely read you. Let's get the  hell out of here!
Is anyone there? Can anyone read me?
Phil gets no response. He is shaking, almost crying. He  hesitates, then starts hitting some keys.
Which reads: "PRE-LAUNCH CHECKLIST."

McConnell has shed his backpack, with its unneeded oxygen tank. He steps cautiously onto the colored rings. Nothing seems to happen. Moving further, he takes his place on th indigo circle at their core. He looks at
As it dips from orange into red; the BELL TONES are conti now, very deep and rapid.

The rover, with Luke and Terri inside, races away towards the safety of the ERV, as the maelstrom boils over the Fa behind them. The sky is purplish black, thick with flying debris and eerie lightning flashes. Towering billows of d chase them over the plain, nearly enveloping them as they speed towards us, passing OUT OF FRAME.
McConnell reacts, surprised, as suddenly

Begins to rise around him, swiftly and smoothly, coming u from the circumference of the indigo circle. Then a second, identical cylinder -- the top half -- drop down from somewhere overhead. The two sections meet and f in a flash of light, containing McConnell inside them, as neatly as if he were in a giant, transparent mailing tube

Fights against a stab of claustrophobia. Is he being  imprisoned? Or somehow protected? Either way, he's virtua immobilized. In this tight space in his bulky suit, he ca even move his arms. Only his head and neck can still shif
Phil is going over his final pre-launch checklist, flippi switches and pressing buttons. He looks at his
Which reads "1350."
His finger hovers over a "Fire" button. He licks his lips nervously, squeezes his eyes shut, and hits the button.
And the words: "IGNITION SEQUENCE INITIATED"
McConnell is straining inside the cylinder that surrounds him, when something catches his attention. He arches his  neck, looking down.
Is beginning to fill the cylinder! It swirls in, from som unknown source, rising rapidly; already his lower boots a covered.
Widen in alarm. He strains against the sides of the cylin but
Slide helplessly across the smooth surface.
Looks down again.
Is up to his knees. Now his thighs...
Cranes his neck, staring up. Can he wedge himself higher, can he somehow climb to safety?

The entire "ceiling" of the Face is becoming translucent. can see the dust storm, boiling overhead. And now, rising into this, are fiery coils of energy from the Face itself These swirl and twist in every direction, like angry wate snakes; battered by the fierce winds. Two vast forces on collision course.
Luke drives the rover through the blinding storm, as Terr stares at a dashboard computer screen. They have to shout be heard over the ROARING WIND.
I've lost the Base Camp beacon!
Luke looks over alarmed.
As the needle spins freely, giving no direction whatsoeve
No good! We're driving blind.
I'll try to keep on a straight line!  It's our only chance.
Don't worry! I've worked with Phil  for four years! I know Jim gave him  a direct order, but he won't leave  without us.
The Rover races towards us, the front of the storm chasin it from behind, then completely overtaking the Rover. It  disappears from view!
Phil sits in the pilot's seat. He is looking at a compute graphic that shows the engines readying to launch. With  resignation, he keys his mike.
This is ERV, do you read? ERV to  Rover, do you read...?

Phil waits a second, then reaches slowly for a blinking r switch that reads "LAUNCH." He hesitates, then actually h his fingers on it, about to flip it, when he hears a crac of static on the radio. Phil keys his mike.
This is ERV, do you read?
(very faint) Save the fuel, Phil. We're coming  in.
And Phil chokes back a sob. Blinking back the tears, he t to compose himself, then keys his mike.
Uh, Phil's not here right now. He  left for Earth five minutes ago.  Please leave your message at the  beep.

FROM GROUND LEVEL we see that the coils of energy are ris from the forehead of the Face, from its "third eye," spin and looping faster and faster, starting to form a vortex. But unlike the wind vortex that killed the Mars One crew, this is a vortex of fire. As we watch, more fiery streaks begin to emerge from the sides of the Face, from the chin cheeks and temples. These all rush upwards, like lava flo uphill, gathering in intensity as they leap free of the F itself and spiral into the atmosphere. The peak of the fo vortex is already piercing the lowest layer of storm clou causing a dark counter-swirl.

head_text.subj: EXT. MARS ONE BASE CAMP. NIGHT

text: Phil stands at the bottom of the ERV's ladder, gripping i to steady himself, staring into the swirling dust. THE ROVER appears out of the dust and sand, the immense s seeming to chase it from behind. Luke and Terri climb out struggle towards him through the wind. Phil grips their h helping them over to the ladder. He looks back, confused.
Where's Jim?
He got another ride.
Phil stares at her, bewildered.
Tell you on the way. Let's go!
Sequence omitted from original script.

LOOKING DOWN INTO THE CYLINDER, we see that the cobalt-bl fluid has risen to McConnell's upper chest. Now it's at h shoulders! It pours into his suit through his neck ring. He strains on tiptoes, craning his head back, trying to k his unhelmeted face above the rising liquid. He sucks in deep desperate gulps of air, his head thrashi from side to side. Then suddenly the fluid is over his mo his nose, his forehead. His whole body is submerged! The level of fluid continues to rise towards the unseen t of the cylinder.
Squeezes his eyes shut, holding his breath. Not so much  fighting this anymore as simply floating in place, waitin for his inevitable death...

WIDEVIEW FROM ABOVE, as the energy vortex bends from side side, pushing back the swirling storm that surrounds the  Face. And REVEALS, in CLOSEUP, the beautiful face, the shining  eyes of MAGGIE McCONNELL. Beatific, eternal. She gazes  directly INTO CAMERA, then smiles...
Smiles back.

Through their cockpit window, they watch the Martian ship hurtle by them at a hundred times their speed.
